text: Medium brown pour, quick off white head. Nose is dates, brown sugar, maybe some Madiera. Middle is sweet malt, plums, some caramel, light fruitiness. Finish is fruity and sweet.

The oak aging here definitely does this one justice. Smells and tastes of oak and caramel. Additional flavours of dried fruits, brown sugar, and toffee. Woodsy notes are definitely not overwhelming. Very clean finish without the syrupy mouth that some of these aged brews risk. Could use a touch more carb.

Bottled at dusty's. Lots of Caramel malt character. Not overly boozy. Warming. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sherry smells with some orange. Deep golden orange with thick tight white head with microscopic bubbles short but persistent head. Beautiful complex tastes of orange, alcohol, sherry. A really nice ale.
550ml bottle @ 8%. Nutty brown colour, frothy off white head that fizzed away quickly. Caramel and alcohol aroma, flavour is toffee, dried fruit, most pleasant

550ml bottle [8.0%]. Clear, nutbrown colour small to average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Sweatish malty, slightly fruity hoppy aroma, notes of red berries, cherry, raisin, all alcohol soaked, hints of toffee, a touch of nougat and oak; fruity flavours are rather ephemeral, subtle hints of liquorice. Taste is slightly sweet malty, dry, slightly fruity, minimally papery, hoppy overtones, a toffee basic layer, some nougat thereupon, notes of alcohol soaked raisin, a touch of oak; warming alcoholic finish.

Bottle from Boise Co-op. Hazy, dark amber, high fluffy head, very creamy, clumpy lacing. Boozy aroma, raisins, molasses, Christmas pudding. Taste is sweet, alcohol burns a little, more plums and raisins. Sweetness lingers, with a little warmth. Really nice.

Bottled in 2014, this Yorkshire Stingo leaves much to be desired on the aroma. Strong on stone fruits, smells damp (presumably from soaking in the barrels), oaky. Maybe some yeast. A little spice.

Appearance is amber, rose, copper. Head quickly reduces to a solid ring around the glass after pour.

Taste is wonderful. A quick and pronounced hops flavor moves immediately to malted caramel, which lingers until it turns alcoholic, which pleasantly and warmly transitions to fruit (raisin and fig). Fruit lingers, undernotes of oak emerge, leaving a pleasant spice (nutmeg, a SLIGHT hint of cinnamon) aftertaste.

Mouthfeel is watery, dry, quickly fleeting. Its surprisingly light considering the prominent malt and caramel flavor. 

Overall - a rare treat. There are better beers from Smiths, but this brew is hardly forgettable.

A lovely colour in the tankard and a small but impressive head. The flavours were fantastic, with malt and bitter hops with a top coat of sweet and soft vanilla from the time in the barrels. There was coffee, port and a slight burnt flavour that was lurking in the background. The beer was almost winelike and that is a compliment. It was really, really nice beer and there is not much more to say.

Bottle at 8%. Pours ruby copper with a small head that soon disperses. Flavour is sweet caramel, dried fruits... body is bit thin and a touch watery. Not bad, but I feel it needs a bit more body and flavour.
500ml bottle. Red with a fluffy head. Has a nutty, red fruity, candied orange vibe to it. In the taste there is a sweeter, chocolatey, dryish end to proceedings. Not bad.

(bottle) hazy deep amber-ruby colour with a frothy light-beige head. aroma of brown sugar and fudge, slightly oxidized, with some notes of bran flakes, floral hops and ethanolic oak. flavour is mostly ethanol, raisins and toffee, with some light salted liquorice, dark fruit and a rathery dry treebark finish. heavy-bodied with soft carbonation.

550 mL bottle from 2014 shared by ebone1988. The pour is a darker coppery brown with a thick khaki colored head that falls to a thin film and light ring without any lace. The aroma is really sweet. There is a dusty oxidized cardboard thing happening and a darker fruit and caramel malt going on. Its pretty good but leaves a little bit to be desired. The flavor is similar. There is a sharp hop happening with the cardboard and light fruitiness. Its really interesting. Like a cross between a barleywine and an amber. The mouth feel is lighter and slightly stronger carbonated with a lingeringly sweet fruit, caramel, and cardboard on the back end. Its a decent beer, but its a little oxidized and messy.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Vintage 2014. Aroma is caramel, dark fruit, toffee, sweet, candy, malty, good. Appearance is amber brown, light tan head, somewhat hazy. Taste is caramel, wood, metallic, dark but sweet fruit, dry, nice but lighter flavor than I wanted. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, caramel and sweet dark fruit metallic aftertaste. Overall, I like it but expected slightly better for the price.

BOTTLE 55 CL. Clear dark ruby-brown, beige head. Rich malts and dark fruit gone fermenting, light winey notes, some alcohol (alcohol infused fruit). Rich malty and fruity taste, alcohol adding complexity. Full-bodied, yet easy dining. A little less complexity here, but still great.
Brown. Malt forward, toasted, slight wood notes, raisin. Full body. Finish is lingering sweet malt. I was underwhelmed with this one.

Aroma out of the bottle is almost a citrusy ,brown sugar with a buttery , earthy finish. Appearance is copper, but murky. Taste is not heavy, slighty bitter brown sugar. Very drinkable. . Overall somewhat disappointed. Did not feel that its anywhere near the best in its class

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Aroma of toffee and malt, imbued with a little alcohol. Cloudy dark brown color, smooth beige head that rests at 1", waves of lace. Taste is malt that blossoms into toffee and alcohol, then oak. Full-bodied, more alcohol than 8% implies, almost too much for me to drink in one session. Good, but, for me, Sam Smiths other offerings are more appealing.
Dark ,amber color. Big , yellowish head. Aroma of toasted malt, bread, raisins and wood. Same notes in rich and balanced taste. Full body, Warming finish . Oak notes in aftertaste.

Butelka 0,55l Kolor ciemnobursztynowy, piana biała, średnia ładnie osiada na szkle. Aromat owocowy, bardzo orzeźwiający, słodowy. W smaku to samo razem z chlebowym posmakiem. Karmel i owoce na podniebieniu, raczej słodkie, alkohol ukryty genialnie, wspaniałe piwo.

Aroma:

Medium aroma of malts, caramel, oak, dried fruit and bread.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque orange/brown beer with heavy yeast and with a slight/medium beige head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium/heavy sweet with malts, caramel, oak and dried fruit; ends slightly dry with bread.

Overall:

This beer is rather intense, complex and balanced. Again that cane sugar this brewery always uses. Thankfully the oak adds to the complexity in a great way.

I bought this bottle because Im a fan of oak-aged beers. While this is not the bourbon-barrel-aged variety to which I typically gravitate, it does not disappoint  and is undoubtedly more refined in flavor because its from a non-charred aging oak barrel. 

Big bottle pours a hazy red-orange-brown color. There is light-tan medium-height foaming from carbonating yeast eager to get out of the bottle. Virtually no Belgians lacing on glass. 
Aroma is perplexing. Through the earthy overtones, I faintly make out dates, figs, toffee, raisins, brown sugar and caramel.

A slow sip brings to the taste buds all of what was hinted at from the nose, adding in a sweet, buttery coffee cake. Talk about effective foreplay! Drinks smoothly, as if sipping anejo rum  and, if I let my mind wander just a bit, perhaps sipping it by the fireplace on a cold fall afternoon, petting the dog beside me, and reading the newspaper. For 8 percent alcohol, theres virtually no booze sting on the tongue  very smooth!

The Yorkshire Stengo is a medium-bodied with a creamy-smooth mouthfeel and a non-cloying semi-dry finish, which is surprising for such a malt-forward ale.

Overall, I found this beer to be skillfully brewed and aged. It is well-balanced and tasty.
Old rating from bottle. Brown color, sweet malty aroma, also malt in the taste.
Bottle. Brown with little offwhite head. Aroma sweet malts. Taste sweet malts, very fresh.

Pours reddish brown hazy. Off white reddish foam. Nose is complex and reminiscent of Cognac / port. Roasted bread, plumb, brown sugar and grapes. Taste is equally complex - raisin, brown sugar, bread, plumb, and yes pudding as notes on the label. The Finnish id warm and medium sweet. Very nice glass
Pours a light caramel brown color with a big foamy white head. Pleasant semi sweet aroma. Very smooth but flavors arent very bold. OK but not really that special.

Bottle 550ml (8% version). Served at room temperature. Pours a hazy burnt copper. Head is large, dense, off white and lasts beautifully in the glass. Aroma is rich and complex with notes of spiced Christmas pudding, cognac, dates, glazed orange slices, burnt caramel sauce, aniseed balls (red), earthy casks and rum chocolate (light). Flavour is smooth and vinous, with a very light earthy hop bitterness, port, prunes, raisin toast, rum chocolate, spiced/earthy wood, aniseed (light), and light notes of treacle. Full bodied with soft carbonation, an oily texture and a good length, warming finish.
16 oz bottle. orange-y amber with a thick tan head, but minimal lace. Aroma is sweet, oaky, vanilla, dried fruit. Flavor is sweet, malty, fruity, apple, raisin, drying oak, vanilla.

Pours orangy brown with a light white head. Lots of big malt and slight metallic taste. Apple and pear flavors. Nice oaky finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A lovely sweet ale, with strong mango, pineapple notes, a sharp bitterness, and a thick mouthfeel.

Drank from a pint glass, poured from a 550ml bottle, brewed in 2009! Super oaky aromas, & raisins. Pours a beautiful deep, dark copper color, with a bit of white head. Super smooth, and light in body. Malt forward, with wonderful flavors of oak. Awesome brew, I need to grab some more of this and condition it longer!

50cl bottle from the Red Lion. 
Thick creamy white head. Clear amber pour. Some treacle and barrel notes. Very good beer but very expensive, 9,43 pounds.

Deep bronze with nice fine lacing. Fruitcake, tea, some spices, light woodiness, some booze. Taste is medium sweet and tangy with a rich old ale finish and a tangy dryness. If anything the body is little light but a minor point.

Amber/oranjekleurig bier met beige schuimkraag. Geur: vineus, wat oxidatie, wat sinaasappel. Smaak: rozijntjes, madeira, kandij, alcoholisch. Medium volmondig. Afdronk: bitterig  zoetig, warm alcoholisch. Leuk degustatiebier.
Brunröd öl med ett bra beig skum. Doft och smak av karamell, frukter, övermogna och torkade, söt maltighet. Något för söt för min smak.

*Old rating. Intense brown beginning. Dried fruit, smooth malt. Hints of wood sourness. The beer is complex and intense. Cake, dried plums, hints of alcohol. Long and intense malty aftertaste with a moderate bitterness. Great stuff!

Brewed in 2010, so, aged 5.5-6 years? Murky deep brownish plummy hue, like mashed dates, with a very small ivory head. Amazing aroma with loads of caramelly dates and plums, a bit of English muffin and light toast tones. Smooth malt driven flavor with loads of raisin/dates with a fruity sweet undertone. Its like they brewed a quad using an English ale yeast, giving it that English muffin/light toffee nuance throughout.
Amber brown pour. Not much head. Caramel, toffee rum raisins and oak and vanilla. Pretty thin mouthful.
Caramel aromas, nutty, some vanilla. Somewhat hazy burnt orange with a fairly lasting white head. Pretty sweet. Medium-full bodied.

550ml bottle. (8.0%ABV) Pours a hazy red-copper with a large, frothy, long lasting, beige head that laces nicely. Sweet aroma of dark fruit, (raisin, plum, fig, prune) caramel malt and oak. Sweet flavour of overripe fruit, caramel malt and oak with a slight alcohol burn in a dry finish. Medium body with a smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. An excellent
English Strong Ale.

Bottle (8.0% ABV) from Cork & Cask. Hazy amber body with a thin off-white head. Faint lacing. Aroma of fig, raisins, honey and apricot jam. Flavour of tangy Earl Grey tea, oak and stewed berries. Barely a hint of alcohol. Medium body with a smooth, cask-like mouthfeel. Light carbonation prickle. A luscious, indulgent beer. Top quality.

Appearance: nearly opaque amber-brown with one finger of medium dense ivory head, good retention and minimal lacing. (3/5) Aroma: raisin, stone fruit, toffee, slightly vinous oak. (8/10) Taste: moderate sweet, mild bitter, mild tart, mild alcohol. (8/10) Palate: medium slightly slick body, lively to moderate carbonation, lightly tart and warming finish. (4/5)

English Strong Ale? Thats about as helpful a designation as American Strong Ale - which is to say, no bloody use whatsoever. Personally, I call this a barleywine - though its got elements of a quad or abt, as well. Its not overly complex, but I have to say, I enjoy it. It doesnt seem like the combination of sweet dark fruit and almost white wine vinous characteristics would work all that well, but in fact it does. In particular, the tartness on the tongue persists through the finish and stops the toffee malt from becoming mouth-coating or cloying - think christmas pudding with a not-too-sweet lemon sauce. (15/20)
Bottle at Prufs in Seattle. Rich banana brown, sugary toffee. Nice English style barleywine. Tasty, sweet, nice.

50cl bottle at home. Hazy dark amber brown with a medium slightly off-white head. Medium to full body with low carbonation. Well balanced sweet and bitter tones. Raisins, ripe fruits, caramel, malts, some warming alcohol and spices. Very rich full flavoured brew. Nice!

Aroma - dark fruit, toffee, and vanilla
Appearance - mahogany body. With 1" off-white head that settles to a foam.
Taste - raisins, toffee, burnt sugar, vanilla, and whippin oakened alcohol.
Palate - medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, astringent alcohol.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 butelka, warka do ladne, klarowne, ciemnobursztynowe z rubinowymi przbelyskami piwo z niewysoka, acz ladna, kremowa piana. aromaty owocowo-slodowe, sa wisnie, sliwki, jest chleb, karmel i krakersy. sa tez juz w tle jakies nutki beczkowe faktycznie i miod. w smaku slodkawo, nieco w strone dubla badz quada. lekko winni, chyba nawte lekkie taniny. wanilii czy innych takich beczkowych nie czuje. goryczka niewysoka, wysycenie srednie z minusem, alkohol przyzwoicie schowany. pite z duza przyjemnoscia.Ocena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).

Bottle 550 ml, pours clear amber with strong, pillowy and long lasting creamy coloured head. Aroma of raisins toffee, vanilla and oak wood. Not very complex but pleasant aroma. In taste sweetness goes fluently over into some light bitterness with a slightly tart accent. Besides the sweetish beginning the ale is quite dry. When it warms up a little bit it gains additionaly some tannin a wine notes.

Bronze beer with a thin, white head. Malty, caramel aroma. Looks and smells unremarkable but taste-wise its the business. Malt, caramel, rich fruit with a touch of bitterness as well. A properly beefy, hearty beer. But for the strength I could drink this all day.
550ml bottle. Pours mahogany with good ivory head. Massive oak influence with berries and slight sherry warmth with a hint of aunty marjorys trifle. A classic.
16.9 oz bottle pours hazy Amber with a off white head. Aroma of dried fruit, oak and grains. Taste is oak, raisins, plums and toffee.
Bottle at home. Ruby murky pour small beige head. Nose is of dried fruits, malt, and wood. Tastes of plums, caramel, raisins, malt, woody, some red fruits. Zippy and fruity finish. Tasty beer.

Where: Old Line Fine Wine Spirits & Bistro. 
How: 550 ml bottle.
Appearance: Dark amber brown, small cream colored head. 
Aroma: Boozy and raisins. 
Taste: Fruits, dark and sweet. 
Palate: Medium bodied. 
Overall: I wanted to like it more but just didnt love it. Pretty good.

Immediately one of my favorites, after already-high expectations from the rest of this brewers lineup.

Slightly cloudy mahogany pour in a tulip, holding a clingy finger of dense foam. The aromas of raisin, prune, and caramel seem a mix of elements from my two favorite styles: dopplebock and belgian quad. Indeed, I already know this is a favorite before tasting, but the flavor only reinforces the sweet, ripe-dark-fruit flavors and clean non-cloying finish. Wish Id bought more than one. Back to the store...

Poured a clear medium amber with a thin broken white head. The aroma is sweet malt, light spice, rich red berry fruit. The flavour is moderate to strong bitter with a rich alcoholic bitter, smooth fruity light liqourice palate. Full to medium bodied with soft carbonation. A real winter warmer.
Bottle thanks to s_Hartshorne, cheers Shane. Ruby amber beer with small head. Aroma of toffee and malts. Taste is malts, toffee, some spice and fruity. Very good.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from s_hartshorne cheers Shane; clear amber pour with a thin beige head, aroma has dark fruits and some wood, taste has red fruits, sweet caramel.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2016 Bottle into pint glass. Sweet and alcoholic beer. The sweetness apparently comes from the oak casks used that are more the a century old and used to carry fruit, raisins and treacle toffee. However the more likely reason is the interesting addition of cane sugar. This is probably the reason for its light natural fizz.

Its a dark ruby colour with some natural sediment. The flavour is that of a traditional strong British ale with the added date flavour. It is very pleasant and tasty but I can imagine it getting sickly after a while. The taste is very smiler to dates followed by the strong dry flavour you expect of a beer of this strength.

Very much worth trying and gets you very pleasantly drunk. Giving you a nice warm glow after a single pint. Its perfect for the festive season. 
Score: Aroma 8, Appearance 2, taste 2, Palate 4, Overall 14.
------- Since trying it I have learnt to taste beers better so now having it for a second time Im impressed. It tastes less sweet for some reason, and it has a silky smooth texture. Very nice. Its actually an incredibly beer, with the alcohol perfectly balancing the sweetness. It has a Belgium beer like warmth to it as well. The Main thing to it is that its unique, there is nothing quite like it. That said it gets sickly sweet
slight malt and oak aroma. light brown and hazy in color with little head. taste is malty, hints of raison and plum, slight oak flavor, faint sourness

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Pours a beautiful red-amber with a frothy head. Nose is a bit too boozy, but with rich sweet malt. Palate is rich, sweet, creamy, with caramel malt. A long powerful finish.

Bottle shared at The Cads 10 year get together. 29/03/2015. Thanks to whomever brought this one. Reddy / caramel brown coloured pour with a thin off white head. Aroma is honey malts, plum, caramel. Flavour is composed of sweet sticky caramel malts, toffee, honey, little earth. Palate is sticky sweety, moderate carbonation, viscous. Lingering raisin and caramel and oak.

Bottle. 8%. A clear deep amber colour with a medium off white head. Aroma of toffee, some fruitcake, raisin, slight red berries, a little orange, subtle oak and treacle. Taste is similar of toffee, fruitcake, treacle, raisin, some brown sugar, subtle prune, a little vanilla and some oak. Medium bodied and a slightly oily texture. A sweetish, warming, oaky, vanilla finish. Feels like a Christmas beer this, full of spices, fruitcake flavours and some alcohol warmth. Tasty.

Aroma is toffee, biscuit, toffee, caramel, mineral water, licorice and deeply roasted malts . Taste is rich sweet malts, caramel and toffee. A light earthy hop note with pleasant ground water body. Appearance is a slightly hazy amber with a thin pearl head that retains fairly well.
Bottle at KØ 15. Clear orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, fruit, hops, malt and raisins.
Bottle into pint glass. Pours a hazy brown colour with a thin tan head. Aroma is stone fruit and marmalade. Taste is marmalade, a little oakiness and stone fruit. Pretty nice beer.

Bottle:
Cloudy brown with a small beige head.
Raisin, toffee aroma.
Sweet, dark fruit, caramel malt, woody flavour.
Alcohol presents a slight warmth, but very mild.
Nice and easy drinking for 9%

Live rating of a 500ml bottle from Glug Newcastle, bottle states 8% ABV. Served cellar cool in a Hoegaarden Grand Cru snifter. Cough linctus and treacle toffee aroma rising from bottle and glass Beautiful russet brown body with a proud creamy off white head. Powerfully flavoursome. Christmas cake, treacle toffee, oakiness, and an astringent hint of balsamic vinegar. Full-bodied, slightly oily, long chewy finish. Im absolutely loving this.

Bottle. Sensoric. Deep red, little hazy with medium, semi-densed light brown head. Poor lacing and head retention. Nice malty (caramel) and fruity aroma - dark and red fruits. SOme alcohol in the background, soem oak hint of spices.taste is semi-sweet (candy like), with some alcohol noticable. Medium body, thick texture, average carbonation. In general very drinkable, semi-sweet beer.

Drunk from 50cl bottle bought from Bierhuis in Ossett. Strong dark ale.

Bottle
Aroma-honey, fruits
Appearance-amber, hazy, beige foam
Taste-light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, 
Pałate-full body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter finish
Overall-very good

Old 8% bottle, bb june 2015. Pours amber/ruby with an off white head.
Aroma: caramel, nuts, spices, dried apple. Taste: chocolate fudge, plums, raisins, chipolata pudding, walnut, vanilla, oak, spices. Medium sweet, light bitterness, full body, creamy to sticky texture, soft carbonation, lingering nutty and dark fruit finish.
Bottle. Candied sugar, toffee malt, and straw aroma. Cloudy brown-amber with large light tan head. Sweet rock candy, toffee malt, and moderately bitter herbal flavor. Light alcohol finish. Nice.

Bottle; pours clear amber with a beige head; sweet dark fruit aroma with caramel, alcohol, and oak; taste is sweet with dark fruits, caramel, and a hint of spice; finish is dry and bitter with oak and a little spice; another good beer from Samuel Smith

NIce barrel aroma, vanilla oak. Quick fading head. Taste is carbonation, sweetness, barrel, light vanilla. no sour (impressive for cask). Palate is a bit overcarbonated but full body (expected at 9%) Overall a nice beer. Its like Firestone walker DBA on steroids.

Ale inglese da carattere! Colore ambrato scuro con schiuma pannosa. Al naso molto profumata con note di brandy. In bocca corposa, ben bilanciata tra dolcezza e secchezza. Il sapore ricorda la frutta candita in liquore con un punto biscottato. Finale persistente. Un grande classico ma non molto beverina... una birra da "divano"

Bottle at the Maypole, Cambridge. £8.00 but I know it can run upward of £12 in London, and you gotta spend money to make money... Light brown with a rust/orange hue. Ive poured this badly & given it a fairly big cream-coloured head. Aroma isnt all that forthcoming: raisins/figs and a bit of sour mash whiskey. Sweet/spicy taste, intense and chewy. A fair bit of hop bitterness in the finish. Nice chewy palette with gum-numbing carbonation. Its good, but not mind-blowingly so, and to be honest with the price and the hype, a little more intensity wouldnt go amiss.
They dont do much wrong at Samuel Smiths. This is yet another great beer from Tadcaster. Rich aroma, full-bodied, somewhat smoky, a very finely-tuned brew. And I just love that artwork.

Pours two fingers of head on a cloudy dark straw body.
The aroma is dark grains, oak and a little candy.
The taste is earthy, dirt, and dark fruits. Mild sweetness.
The texture is medium.
Interesting.

Bottle at the Cads 10th Anniversary bash, 29/03/15.
Hazed orange amber with a moderate off white covering.
Nose is rich fruit, spice, raisens, malt, fruit cake mix.
Taste comprises spiec, toffee, rich fruit loaf, dates, mince meat, toffee.
Medium + body, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Decent strong, plenty of depth in this number.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from a deli in Northallerton. Pours amber with a frothy cream head that fades quite quickly. The taste is quite sharp, sour citrus with orange notes especially. Some cough medicine notes along with noticable booze. A little oak in the finish. A interesting beer that wasnt quite what i was expecting.

Aroma: alcohol, leather, oak
Appearance: amber, hazy, minimal head, brown foam, 
Taste: light sweetness, lightly sour, 
Palate: medium body, slick feel, soft carbonation, astringent, long finish,
Aged in oak for a year, gives this awesome brew a hint of tawny port. The result is incredible.

Bottle shared at The Cads 10 Year Ratebeer Anniversary. Clear chestnut brown, thin Borge head. Nose is fruity, medicinal, Vimto, sweet, tangy, strong alcoholic ale. Taste is Orange, Grand Marnier, fruity, tangy, malty, alcoholic.

Bottle shared at the Cads Shindig. Bottled in 2011, BB June 2014, 9%. Hazy red brown, still, small ring of tan head. Aroma is toffee, some minty pine, raisin. Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is bready, caramel and toffee, dry and oaky, dark dried fruits, light bitterness.

At cellar temperature and into a snifter. Mildly hazy, it settles and auburn chestnut with moderate effervescence and a fuelled, but not efficiently lofted off white crown. Aroma is tart, plump with dark stonefruit and underripe berries, Merlot grapes, musk candy and fruity, cheap perfume. Vinous and plump yet light in body like a good red. Tight and tart with plenty of dark stonefruit coming through - plummy and raw. Nice length of fruit; sherryish and deliciously aged. Oxidised to be quite vinous but the alcohol is hellishly masked. This is an old ale that is approachable, tempting and likeable. Not complex, but pretty sumptuous! (55cL, BBE 06/15, 8.0% ABV, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)
Hazy brown, aromas of oak, sweetness, malt, raisin. Taste was sweet, oaky, malty, with a slight alcohol burn. Needs to tame a bit. Not my favorite.

Pours hazy brown with a large head.
Nose shows honey, cardboard, prunes, sultanas.
Sweet and rich flavours, vanilla oak, malt, sultanas, caramel. Dries out in the finish creating a slightly abrasive contrast to the initial flavours.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2016 [3/15] Bottle, 8% ABV, bb 7/15. 11C. Darkish amber with a modest beige head that lasts pretty well. Boozy aroma with prunes, raisins, toffee, oak, fruitcake spices, white pepper. Sweet and luscious with some Madeira-like flavours. Toffee, dark fruits, spices. Finish is quite bitter and oaky with enough spices to relieve the sweetness. Been wanting to try this one for ages and only the price wasnt what Id hoped. [4.0]Cant see a date on this one, but still at 8%. This time the fruit cake is stollen complete with a seam of marzipan.

Pours an opaque brown/red with a medium tan head. Aroma has lots of dark fruit, toffe, caramel, sherry and a bit of booze. Flavor follows suit...toffee really stands out...lots of oakiness and earthy bitterness. Mouthfeel is full and silky with a dry earthy/oaky finish that hints at dark fruits.
Ruby brown appearance. Mild toffee caramel aroma. Taste is some easy going dark fruits and toffee. Nice English style ale here.
Butelka do 06.2015. Kolor miedziany, piana obfita. Aromaty słodowe, suszone owocowe, cherry. Alkohol lekko rozgrzewający przy przełtkaniu, przyjemne odczucie.

550ml bottle. Deep amber appearance, a bit hazy, with a medium white head. Aroma is overripe fruits, malt, brown sugar, toffee. Flavour is medium sweet, raisin, prunes, caramel, candy, a touch of whisky. Medium to heavy body, medium carbonation. A good beer for sure, but I was expecting something more...

550 ml bottle. The beer is a hazed copper color with a beige head of foam. Good retention. The aroma has some acidic raisin, oak, dust. As the beer opens up more, the acidity seems to subside and allow more of a mellow sweetness. Thicker mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Not bad, really not what I expected.
Bottle from Stewarts Wine Company 130215. What a great flavour and aftertaste this beer has. Raisins and port soaked currants come to mind. Big whiff of oak in the nose.

Delicious from a 18.7 ounce bottle. Im not going to describe this ale as I always have others, because the commercial description is spot on. ABV at 8% (on this bottle)  is not a factor. Very smooth and drinkable, though complex.

Bottle: Poured a deep amber color ale with large foamy head with good retention and some light lacing. Aroma of nice caramelized malt notes with subtle toffee notes is quite enjoyable. 0.55 bottle still at 8% ABV. Light brown color with a reddish tinge and a yeasty, granulated suspension. Head is thick, off-white, and has a good retention. The appearance was a dark brown close to black color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute leaving some light sticky lacing.
The smell had some dark roasty malts with a nice dark coffee and a light dark fruitiness running all over.
The taste was combined through the previously mentioned flavors.

Barwa: piękna, głęboko miedziana, klarowna. Piana beżowa, drobno pęcherzykowa, dość obfita i trwała oraz ładnie oblepiająca szkło. 

Aromat: owoce czerwone, rodzynki, landrynki, alkohol, może lekkie nuty beczkowe, a nawet wanilia, ale może to już sugestia. 

Smak: zdecydowanie pełny, słodowy (herbatnikowo - karmelowy), umiarkowanie słodki i nieco kwaskowy. Do tego rodzynki i nuta alkoholowa. Występuje chmielowa kontra, ale goryczka najwyżej w okolicach średniej. 

Jest to fermentowane w otwartych kadziach i leżakowane przez rok w dębowych beczkach "prawdziwe ale" (refermentowane w butelce). Problem polega jednak na tym, że wspomniane beczki mają ponad 100 lat, zatem nie oddają zbyt wiele nut charakterystycznych dla leżakowanych w ten sposób piw. Barwa i piana są wzorowe. Aromat zdominowany został przez estry, nieco podobne do piw belgijskich. Smak przyjemnie zbalansowany, ale raczej klasyczny, bez szaleństw. Jeśli ktoś lubi ułożone i zbalansowane trunki, o naprawdę pięknej barwie i trwałej pianie powinien być zadowolony. Niestety leżakowanie w beczce niezbyt wpływa na smak i aromat tego piwa i z tego powodu moim zdaniem jego cena nie jest adekwatna do oferowanej jakości.

550ml Bottle from Evil Eye Lounge (York - £6.00 approx.):
Strong smelling with good malts & toffee plus a nice alcohol edge to it as well. Plenty of ripe & sweet fruits, oak & vanilla featuring. A good smelling beer with a solid balance & the touches of alcohol only improve things, as does the sweetness from the fruits.

Again the sweetness kicks things off with some ripe fruits & vanilla plus the oak from the aroma & I could detect bread & malts with a great balance between flavours. The beer is rounded out with some toffee.

Smooth with an alcohol kick but not much bitterness. Some sweetness is present from the start. The balance of this one was good & despite the strength it was quite an easy one to drink.

Another very good Samuel Smiths beer, strong from the start but it didnt overpower & went down surprisingly easy with a good balance.

When the British (or more usually, the English) wax lyrical about the warm beer of our "sceptred isle", this is the pinnacle of the ale in question. Even though it is best served cellar chilled than warm. It looks like any number of "real ales" served in good pubs up and down the country - brown with a faint hint of ruby, with a small off-white head. Little hop presence so limited immediate aroma, but with warming the aroma of a crisp, brown fruit pudding straight from the oven rises from the glass. Taste is amazing - aforesaid pudding, plums, raisins, toffee, fortified wine, and some herbs.
For those outside of the UK, wanting to know what English ale is all about, try this. Just dont expect them all to be this good.

I poured a 550ml bottle into an English pint glass. I was brewed in 2010, bottled on 1/28/11 and cost $12.99 ($0.69 per ounce).

Appearance: Ugly rusty brown hue. Completely opaque with no visible carbonation. Pours to a small, beige, foamy head which completely dissipates and leaves no lacing.

Smell: A cornucopia of dark and stone fruits, plus notes of sherry and cider.

Taste: I first had Samuel Smiths Yorkshire Stingo over four years ago when it originally debuted. I havent had it since, though re-watching my review I can tell the flavor profile to the beer has definitely changed over time. Like any good English-style barleywine, old ale or English Strong Ale should, its aged and developed nicely. Im not sure which style category it conforms to, though much like the rest of the brews from Samuel Smiths Brewery, its complex, distinctive and quite enjoyable.

The first thing I notice about the palate is the huge fruit notes. Red apple, plum, fig, raisins, and dark cherry are all prominent flavors right away. I also noticed a strong, sweet flavor of butterscotch, though it faded quickly. Toffee emerges on the finish, along with some dark chocolate, giving it a taste profile similar to that of a barleywine, but not quite as intense. Whatever hop presence this beer originally had has definitely faded, though its not quite carbonated syrup either. In my original review I described it as being very cider-like and acidic, though thats not the case anymore. While still plenty flavorful, Id say the beer definitely peaked some time ago. If you see a bottle in the 2 to 3-year-old vintage Id recommend giving it a try.

Drinkability: Samuel Smiths Yorkshire Stingo definitely has the palate of a strong brew, though the drinking process itself it remarkably easy. The mouthfeel is calm, soft and smooth, but noticeably thick. I was surprised (and a tad disappointed) that the aftertaste finishes mostly clean with just a slight dryness. The 8% ABV gives it significant weight and a minor warming sensation, but at no point is there a distraction.

Overall- disappointing. The bottle was brewed in 2011, perhaps a fresher bottle would have better. The Boulevard Collaboration 3- a Stingo-was far superior: more distinct fruit and tart.

Bottle from Top Cellar, Easter Rd, Edinburgh [081013] 2011 bottle
Copper red amber, clear, off white frothy head that dissipates to thin layer, some lacing, good colour
Aroma - caramel malts, raisin, soft spicy notes, some alcohol, candy sugar, dab of sherry
Taste of sweet caramel malts, soft sweet toffee, fruit cake spices, raisin, touch of sherry, candy sugar, soft alcohol, smooth old ale
Palate - Soft carb, medium body, little thin, smooth texture, fairly sweet palate. Finish is quite dry, soft warming alcohol, sweet smooth malts, fairly rapid finish
Overall - This bottle was 2 years old so was very smooth - body a little thin, perhaps not a complex as I had expected, but still a fine old ale
Pours a rich ruby color with off white head. Malt, toffee, caramel, molasses, dark fruit and oak aroma and flavors. Medium body and a sweet oaky finish.
Bottle. Orange brown with minimal head. Not a strong aroma but very smooth caramel flavor. Enjoyable.
Bottle. Copper brown with a beige head. Light toffee and caramel. Mmmm. Good stuff.

Little head, amber color, sediment present. Aroma is malty, with wood notes, caramel, licorice. Moderate body, low carbonation, bitter finish. Alcohol nicely integrated. Taste is fruity, smooth and very well balanced, very easy to drink.

Sam Smiths Stingo is aged in oak barrels which really adds to the complexity of this British beer. I've picked up spice, toffee, and raisins. It's dark almost black color adds to the overall drinking experience.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I just had a couple of pints of Guinness-excellent
Bottle pours dark amber with white head. Aroma is malty toffee and spizy hops. Flavour is malty with caramel and toffee with a little hop caracter and bitterness.

Nice-looking chocolate brown beer with a thin, but creamy white head. Nose of sweet malt, butterscotch, and stewed prunes. Flavor is deliciously rich with a prominent, but not cloying, sweetness initially that is ripe with caramelized sugar, candied nuts, and dried fruit. This develops into a subtle bitterness that compliments the complex initial flavors. Great beer.

(Bottle, 2012 Batch): Pours a dark amber, small off white head. Aroma instantly hits with big oaky, fruity notes along with some sweet bread and a touch of alcohol presence. Sharp fruity sweetness on the tongue straight away, some oaky and wood notes, some kind of alcohol element but more like a sherry taste to it. Really different but lovely.

(Bottle) Hazy dark copper / amber with nice dense tan head. Fairly subtle but pleasant aroma, primarily caramel with possibly hints if oak. Lovely palate; full bodied and creamy, with some stickiness. The taste is pretty impressive and complex. There is a sweet backbone of caramel / treacle, overlaid with several complementary flavours. At the start there is some subtle tangy fruitiness. Through the rest of the palate there is dried fruit, raisins. Towards the finish there is some apparent oak and there is a gentle long lasting bitterness. The are some burnt dark roast notes as well. The alcohol is quite well hidden but is apparent towards the finish, providing a subtle bite. An excellent and unusual beer.

Dirty light brown like iced tea. Thin warm-tan head. Aroma is grass and light juniper berry and hint of strawberry and bread with brown sugar sprinkled on top. Overall a rather tame aroma. Banana comes out when the surface is aggrevated. Banana bread. Medium light body with a somewhat frothy and creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is dry bread crust which melds perfectly into a grainy, smooth bitterness, light brown sugar and whole grain scone. Fruit is subdued plum and raisin. Herbs come out as it warms. Touch of booze despite the restrained 8.0%abv listed on the label. Overall, a bit too restrained for my spoiled American palate, but Id have a hard time finding a strong ale this clean or yeast this carefully paired with malt/hops in the states. Give it some time to breath and it become quite drinkable and addictive. A sessionable strong ale!

550ml bottle served in a Sam Adams Perfect pint glass.

A - Pours a hazy copper brown with 2.5 fingers of cream colored head.

S - Toasted/burnt caramel, sweet nut bread, hints of oak wood, incredible aroma.

T - Dense toasted caramel malt, slight tart fruit notes, dark sweet bread, toffee, mild wood flavors.

M - Medium body with fizzy carbonation.

Very complex nose and delicate but bold malt flavors. Truly enjoyable.

Serving type: bottle

04-04-2012

Murky medium copper pour with a long lasting off white head. Pleasant aroma of toffee, brandy, caramel and a wee bit of alcohol. Full-bodied flavor with a lot of caramel, toffee, baked brown bread and brandy. Thick rich mouthfeel. would make an excellent winter warmer.

Shared bottle at Vlaamsche Reus. Cloudy tawny portlike colour, small off white head. Aroma of raisins, black fruit and some oak. Taste has a lot if raisins, black fruit, some oak aging, hint of vanilla, malt. Good beer!

500ml bottle. Caramel, fruity aromas, some raisins. POurs amber-reddish, quite clear, with nice creamy off-white head, persistent. Medium body, low carbonation, creamy texture. Taste quite malty, some caramel sweet, some fruity and some hints of wood. Quite balanced. Enjoyable.

In short: A fluffy caramelized, fruity and woody copper ale.  Enjoyable sweet beer.
How: Bottle 500ml, consumed a few months after purchase.
The look: Mostly clear copper body topped by a medium beige head.
In long: Nose is toasted, caramelized, a Home Depot store wood smell.  Taste is creamy fluffy caramel, juicy ripe fruits, earth, woody flavor feeling like sawdust.  Plenty of soft bubbles creating a full but light creamy mouthfeel.  On the minus side it is a ver simple beer, not much complexity here, a bit too sweet for me.  But on the plus side it is very cohesive beer, refreshing flavors despite the sweetness and it has a pleasant mouthfeel.  The good outweighs the bad, an enjoyable beer.  Samuel Smiths, brewing beer in Yorkshire England for over 250 years, and sometimes I wonder if the person who invented the beer remembers the night he invented beer or if he blacked out and never realized what he did.

At the esbls tasting in Wood River Illinois.  Pours a cloudy red amber coloe with and off white head. Nose of ripe fruit some figs and raisin.  Medium body.  Flavor of o rich caramel malts and some oak Finishes with some sour notes. Quite tasty

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2014 Poured into a english pint. Paired with pizza. :)

Aroma is light but it may be because of the glassware selection. Boozy. Oaky. Earthy.
Appearance is interesting. Hazy oak brown. Like... dirty or something. It looks fun.
Taste is amazing. A great balance of oaken booze with some fruit notes, like plumb and currant. A bit of hops. Boozy kick has a fresh finish.
P: Interesting on the palate. Great flavor development. Boozy but the finish is very smooth and fresh. 

This beer is amazing. It has all the qualities of a long barrel aged beer but also brings a great freshness and drinkability. Reminds me of an easier to drink JW Lees. Has all the great qualities but does it better.

Doing another one for an aged bottle. Yeah old ales do not age well. This bottle was from 2010 and Im breaking it out 2014. Just... boring. Watery. like a really watery whiskey. Im done with this ageing experiment. Stouts stay the same, old ale worse, barleywine better, belgian better. Cool.

Clear copper amber with small off-white foam head. Aroma is bit weak. Taste is quite different, different mixture. Little fruity, little scotch, little woody. Aftertaste is long lasting, barley, woody. (Velp 201304)

Hazy brownish-orange pour with a white head.  The aroma has a somewhat wine-like quality with grape and mild apple.  It has a light, thin body with soft carbonation.  The taste is mildly sweet with some noticeable alcohol.

550ml bottle. Pours a hazy reddish amber with a 1/2" of off white head. Head recedes quickly leaving minimal lace. Aroma has a lot going on. Quite fruity with scents of raisin, date, fig and herbil hops, all with a wonderful woody undertone. Taste imparts both sweet, with some brown sugar, caramel and toffee, and sour with an oaken acidity that creates an interesting balance. Towards the full side in body with smoothness that demands savoring. Very nice indeed.

Rated 3/24/13. 
Portion of a 500ml bottle into a Hunahpus snifter. From notes.

A: Pours a dark copper color. The head is a one finger cream shade.

S: Theres a lot of sweet caramel and brown sugar which I half expected. What really struck me is the strong vanilla qualities the aroma also provides.

T: This has a lot of vanilla to open the flavor profile. After a bit, raisin/caramel sweetness gives way to a balanced, dry mineral finish. Really pleasant, and complex to boot.

M: I really like the creaminess of this one. The body is of medium texture, and it coats the tongue smoothly.

O: This had a level of richness to it that many of the imperial stouts I had that day lacked. Its not super easy to drink, and its kind of pricey, but its a great one to savor slowly.

Pours a reddish brown with a foamy head and steady carbonation. Caramel and toffee malts in the aroma with some dry cherry and blackberry in there. Really smooth brew with no real sign of the 9% abv. Great balanced taste gives you one of the best Yorkshire Ales, bit pricey though but a must try.

500mL for something like $15 or way too much. Pours muddier rusty orange to deep amber. Yellowish creme foam. Nice formation and okay retention. Nose is sweeter cherry juice box, mild toffee and brown sugar. Taste is quite bland with mild red apple and tannic red apple skin and flavorless barrel staves. Palate is papery, chalky, very bland. Almost no flavor at all. 6/4/5/3/11=2.9

50cl. bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy red color with a smal off-white head. Aroma of malt and spices. Taste has lots of malt, dark fruits, spices and wood. A bit sweet with a long malty aftertaste. Lots of alcohol in the finish - this one tells you its strong. :-) Really good ale.

had wanted to try this since it was released, and fuck those BA ads- made me want it more .. finally got a bottle at the Flying Saucer, damn pricey though- $22 .. . . lots of dark wood, booze, wet wood, and nrandy (brandy) .. . very english, but thug punch .. . . what part of africa?
Bottle. Dark brown and hazy.  Roasty, toffee, barrel, with a dose of alcohol to kick it in the end. Good beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text:
Poured hazy, dark amber with an excellent head.  The head is durable but left little lacing.  Some odd orange particles suspended in the beer. 
Aroma: features fruit, grains and biscuit plus some oak barrel.
Taste: ABV partly hidden; oak aging. 
M: medium body; medium+ carbonation; smooth; almost no sign of the alcohol. 
O: a refined strong ale.

Bottle. 2009 vintage and cellared since. Pours a dark brown color. Nose has some definitely malty sweetness in there with some muted fruit elements and a little caramel. Taste is also very slightly sweet with some toasting. Smooth. This one aged well.

Bottle, label says brewed in 2011.  Nose is heavily alcoholic and medicinal, herbs with vanilla and faint cherry.  Deep caramel color fading into dark brown and supporting a foaming yellow-tinged head.  Taste is much drier than expected, theres raisin-led fruit up front but then the heavy, sludgy waves of treacle, molasses, toffee, caramel swamp everything else but the vanilla and oak fragments, and light yeast.  Gently warming, not a burner or fume-ridden, full-bodied but edging closer to flat.  Seems to be one to let warm above cellar temperature, and a good sipper with a dense and unique malt character and a barrel component that is much classier than usual.

Pours a deep smokey amber with some visible sediment. Its a really nice looking pour but the head thuns out (to a film) too quickly for my taste. Aroma is somewhat hard to find... A balance of malt/hops with some banana & butterscotch... hint (HINT) of cinnamon. The flavor is really the highlight of this brew... Oddly balanced light bitter, light sweet, medium sour. Supping releases strong oak and alcohol notes (which I like). The oily/flat mouthfeel with a bitter finish is main downfall of this wonderful tasting beer. The excellent flavor makes me wish I could rate it higher.

Pours a dark amber with a creamy tan head. Can smell malt and caramel. Tastes include malts, caramels, oak, and a light sweetness. The taste is short on the tongue with complex flavors. Goes well with a good cigar.

50 cl bottle.
Originally rated on 20091001.
Pours clear copper color with a small head. Aroma of ripe fruits, caramel and malts. Flavor of caramel malts, nuts, ripe fruits, toffee and some hay. A bit too sweet and nutty.

Bottled 0,50L. Dark reddish color, much fraught and solid aspect with a long and foamy head resistance. Round and alcoholic aroma, notes of cask, burned wood, little roast malt and stum. A lot winous taste, much flowery start, sweetish body with an elevated alcoholic perception. Pleasant notes of grapes, resin, and cask.
Bottle.  This is a great ale of top quality.  Lots of depth and interesting flavors.  I would like to age one of these further to see how it develops.

55 cl bottle (9,0%) @ OHaras Freehouse. Rated on 01.10.2009
Aroma has toffee, oaky notes, vanilla, raisins and hints of alcohol. Flavour is rather high on oaky notes. Also some toffee typical to English ales, raisins, caramel, alcohol and hints of vanilla. Too stinging flavour, I was expecting better balance here.

550ml bottle from The Naked Grape, Alresford, ABV 9%, my 100th North Yorkshire rating. Pours a glorious pale copper colour with a thin cream coloured head; the aroma is rich and vinous, with a touch of cherry; the cherries are obvious in the mouth as well - reminding me of the orginal Tunes - but theres also a thick oily body below which the alcohol is barely hiding; giving a warming finish with some dry, vanilla oak, and a hint to sip the rest slowly rather than to gulp this done. Certainly a beer to experience, but probably not too frequently.

Bottle conditioned. Murky amber body with a thin white head with poor retention. Hoppy, citrus from English hops, orange, oak, spice, chocolate, red fruit, Mascharino cherries.Sweet, with a dry finish.

500ml bottle. Poured a slightly cloudy dark amber color with a small. Dark fruits, sweet malts, can really feel the alcohol in this one. Flavor is sweet malts, some light roasted notes, dark and dried fruits. Alcohol is extremely noticeable here. Not exactly my thing, though it could have been my attempt at doing all 500ml myself. Had it been a 12oz bottle, things may have turned out differently.

An amazing strong ale. Pours a cinnamon brown with balanced oak aroma and salty taste.Medium body, with lively, but not overwhelming carbonation. Longlasting finish that makes you want to sip it like a fine scotch. Cant wait to have another.
Dark amber/brown color with tan head. slightly fruity aroma. Tastes of wood and fruit. This was not at all what Id hoped.

Pours a clear dark amber with finger of head, nice lacing and good carbonation.  Tropical fruit aroma with sweet malt and toffee.  Oak and vanilla combine with tropical fruit in the taste.  Quite nice and leans more toward the sweet side.   Mouthfeel bit on the thin side but ok.  I really liked it and would drink again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fruit smell, banana and apple.  Slight alcohol taste with oak.  Good would try again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good ale that tastes and drinks a lot like a barley wine. Poured with an amazing head of tight creamy bubbles. However,  probably not worth the price point.

550ml bottle. ABV labeled 8%. Hazy brown / red color. Good thick 1-finger khaki head. Oak, vinous, and dark fruit nose. Medium plus body. Lighter, crisp carbonation. Clean dry finish. Little loose lace. Light sweet bitter notes. Flavor of over ripe dark fruits, wood, and vinous qualities. Above average for Sam Smith in my experience. A fine, decent and interesting and complex ale, but the increased price is not proportionate to the better experience. Was going to share it with my sister staying with me over the holiday, but she didnt care for it one bit.
Very rich beer. You get a sense of the alcohol from the aroma, but it is not heavy on the alcohol to taste. I get toffee and caramel.  A very interesting beer.

This is a reminder of what beer can be and is. While my hat is off to all of the many great U.S. craft beer companiesat the front lines of creating new stylesand producing some great liquid. I feel that Sam Smith is spot on with everything they bring to market.
A very complex swirly brown ale with an off-white head. Notes of toffee are rich and complex on the nose. The ale is smooth but with lots of body. A nice beer to enjoy with friends.

500 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 1/28/2011.  Pours fairly clear reddish brown color with a 1 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Light spotty lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of raisin, prune, toast, toffee, caramel, pear, apple, brown sugar, bread, oak, earth, and light herbal.  Fantastic aromas with great balance and complexity.  Taste of raisin, caramel, toast, toffee, pear, apple, molasses, bread, light oak, light clove, pepper, earth, and herbal spiciness.  Slight bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark and light fruits, caramel, molasses, toast, toffee, earth, clove, light oak, and herbal spiciness on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice malt complexity and balance with the light hop spiciness; with zero cloying flavors present after the finish.  Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a creamy, slick, and slightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden with hardly any warming noticed at all after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent English strong ale.  Very nice amount of flavor complexity and balance; and very smooth to sip on.  A very enjoyable offering as expected.

Has a dark amber color with a light brown head. I smell oak, dark malts and fruits. I taste all of the same with some butter, vanilla, and a touch of nuttyness. I also taste chocolate in the finish. This is a smooth one. Very soft mouth feel. Damn good! Smooth.....

From a 550 ml bottle shared at home.  Brewed in 2011.  Pours a fairly clear deep amber with an off white head.  Lots of sediment floating around.  Malty aroma.  Notes of caramel and orange.  Bitter finish.
Bottle. Pours a reddish brown color. Light carbonation. Aroma is breast and malty with a touch of oak. Flavor is bready and sweet with some maltyness. Easy finish.
550 ml bottle to snifter. Looks good; a mostly opaque amber with off-white lacing. Smells solid; sweet, malty, and oaky. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. Goos stuff.

Pours a deep amber with a coarse tan head. Aroma is toffee, dark fruits, light coffee and nice oaky notes with some acidity. Soft body with flavors of dark fruits, toffee, oak, touches of nuttiness with creamy milk chocolate ending. No noticeable alcohol with it being 9%. Solid beer.

The beer has a dark amber color with some nice lacing in the glass. Aroma of roasted malts and fruit. Taste has more roasted fruits with figs and apricots. There is also roasted malts. Long smooth finish.
I really really like this beer.  The aroma, flavor and aftertaste are all all great.

Complex. Sweet boozy smell. Murky brown tea color with minimal head. Very English in the malt presence, not overly sweet with an alcohol taste mixed in. You can tell this was aged as the flavors blended well. Probably one of the more well-crafted Emglish ales. You have to like this style though.

2010 Bottle. Pours a nice ruby color with a beige head. Aroma is of oak, vanilla, fruitcake, marmalade, forest fruits, toffee, treacle, dark fruits, caramel and slight amount of alcohol. The flavor follows the nose with oak, vanilla, toasted nuts, winegums, fruitcake, butterscotch and lots of fruity esters, I get marmalade, forest fruits and dark fruits, some toffee, caramel and treacle notes too. Body is on the higher side of medium with a silky mouth feel. Overall a nice brew.

Köszönet Armandonak és Balázsnak!
 Olyan színe van, mint egy sűrű vérnarancs italnak, habja sárgás és vékony, de tartós. Illata édeskés, akácvirágos, déli gyümölcsös, mézes és likőrös. Ízében érezni cukordinnyét, török mézet, gyümölcs likőrt, malátát, de mégsem túl édes az egész, mert egy adag komló és tölgyfás aroma egész jól kiegyensúlyozza. Testes sör, kevés buborékkal. Utóíze keserédes, gyümölcsös. Kellemes, behízelgő itóka.
Brown orange color with thin white head. Malty nutty aroma of butterscotch and hints of port. Nice complexity of flavor with cherry wood, toffee, butter and roasted sweet malt
500ml bottle-thin lt tan-amber.  A-sweet med malt.  T-swwet med malt,-caramel, some herbal hops.

Pours a translucent brown from the bottle with thin tan head and and moderate lacing. Aroma is non-existent, taste at least lends a bit of the oak aging, and the booze is well masked. Decent, but not worth the price.
Dark brown pour tan head.  Aroma of fig bread. Taste of bread rum figs.  Medium to light body. Woody pulp character on the end. Hides the alcohol well. Overall this is drinkable but nothing special.

Candied and tropical fruit and woody notes in the aroma.   Crystal clear orange/amber with a reddish tinge and a light tan head.   The candied fruit carries through and now raisins,  plums, caramel and molasses join it.  The texture is creamy and light for a darker and flavorful beer.   While theres lots of sweetness up front, a dry, woodiness swoops in and takes its place for the most part.   A smooth and subtle alcohol warmness arises and with the flavors present makes this a wonderful cold weather beer.  Finishes with more fruity sweetness and wood.  Lots of character and balance, just like the British.
Pours a beautiful red gold with thick cream head. Smells mildly sweet and spicy. Sweet, spicy flavors: toffee, raisins, cream, caramel, dark fruits, spices, oak.  Clean finish.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 10-11-12 Bouteille: Ambrée rougeatre, limpide avec une effervescence normale et un mince collet de mousse. Sublimes aromes de caramel ,dalcool, de fruits rouge, de pain chaud, nez tres complexes. Saveurs délicieuses et variées. Pudding aux raisins, caramel, boisé, mélasse, confiture, chaque gorgée est différente. Bien balancé entre sucré, maltée. Velouté et soyeuse en bouche. Corps asser puissant, finale sur des notes fruitée et alcoolisé. Bière très complexe qui est completement passée sous le radar. Coup de coeur!

Bottle (at 8%) from Middle Farm. It pours clear mahogany brown, with a thick yellowish white head. The nose is caramel, toffee, honey, oak, leather and varnish. The taste is oak, leather, earth, raisin, fruit cake, toffee, treacle, vinous aspect, light spice varnish and warming alcohol with a long, dry finish. Very well balanced, smooth and surprisingly drinkable. A tasty winter warmer.

0,55 l bottle.
Cloudy amber beer with a nice creamy tan head. Cognac, figs and raisins in the aroma with vanilla and some oak. Caramel, raisins and herbs, oak and alcohol, vanila and figs, fruits. Fine

(Note: This is the 2010, 8% abv version)

Poured into standard pint glass. Pours a cloudy amber brown with a finger of off-white head. Some lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, malts, and hints of oak. Flavor is sweet dark fruit up front, plum and cherry notes. Finishes with hints of oak and raisins. Moderate carbonation and medium body with a smooth mouthfeel. Every so slightly astringent finish.
