caramel, nuts, red, amber, brown, clear, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, average carbonation,

Bottle. Pours deep golden with creamy off-white head. Aroma of pears, malt, oxidized malt, grains, biscuits and grains. Flavor is sweet and malty with some yellow apples, caramel, oxidized malt and raisins. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle 500ml @ Geokkjer
Pours clear deep amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, oak and dried fruits. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonaiton is soft.

50cl bottle I picked up at Whole Foods Clarendon.  Pours a hazy, brick red with some creamy, slightly off white head.  Nose is nice, prunes, raisins, toffee, apple, caramel, earthy, a bit dusty.  Flavor is the same, sweet, malty, raisin, dried orange peel, caramel, toffee bits, some cookie dough.  Full, almost dry finish.  Not overly sweet.  Wanted more oak, but I guess this is what beer tasted like 150 years ago.
Aroma is barrel, some malty notes. Flavour is mild caramel, some wood and whiskey. A bit thin but nice.

Dark copper, quite clean and a grey smooth frothy lace. Loads of caramel, candy, quite some hops and some alcohol. Caramel and dark sugar taste, bit astringent but nice. Sticky medium body, good amount of flavour. (33cl bottle at MrHangovers tasting)
Clear amber color beige head. Aroma full of caramel, malts and sweet spices. Flavor is again sweet of caramel and malts and has some hop influences. Very nice.

Bottle @ tasting. Clear amber pour, thin white head. Aroma of caramel, loads of malts, deep plant hops. Somewhat bitter flavor, huge malts, well balanced with decent hop biitterness. Clean and intense. Good beer.
Greatest beer I have ever tasted. I had a 2009; I have another 2009 and a 2008 I plan on opening to celebrate the birth of my second child.
Bottle. Copper colour with a beige head. Aroma is apple, malt, alcohol. Flavour is sweet, apple, oak, malt, alcohol. full body. Easy drinkable beer.

Muddy brown color, no head. Smells of banana, apple, vanilla. Alcohol taste up front that gives way to nice sweet fruity taste. Pretty good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark red-amber colour. Heavy maltyand light hoppy aroma. Caramellic. Heavy bitter nice caramellic flavor. Slightly rustic. Long moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.

The pour is a bottle conditioned hazy medium to dark amber with a moderate head.  There is a toffee-licorice aroma on the nose along with the woodenness of the oak casks.  I loved the aroma but thought Id get a splinter the wood was so upfront.  The body is creamy and medium.  The taste begins with the same pungent barley malt taste that can be likened to a good barleywine but sweeter with a medium lingering finish.  A pretty good beer.

Overripe fruits, vanilla, wood, caramel, wild apples, raisins, and lots of booze in the aroma. Layered and complex, but a bit overwhelming. The taste is milder, maltier, and sweeter, but its still pretty boozy. Plain, watery mouthfeel with practically no carbonation. Id like to try this again, maybe a fresher bottle.

Pours a amber color, oak aromas and has a sweet Carmel taste, pretty good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 vintage I assume. 550ml bottle into a pint glass. $16/bottle bar price...

A - Very dark brown body, almost bordering on black/red. Nice and creamy two finger head with nice lacing.

S - Toffee, dark fruits, caramel, and some spiced bread. A little oaky with some vanilla. Really smooth aroma.

T - Similar to the nose. Christmas spices, bread, toffee and caramel, raisins. Really smooth oak tannin finish. Not overly complex but very tasty. Somewhat chewy and creamy medium bodied mouth feel.

O - Not as spectacular as I was expecting, but very well made and quite delicious on a cold evening. My friend thought it was amazing though.

Medium brown pour, moderate loose head that goes away quickly. Moderate carbonation. Aroma is moderately strong, sweet malt. Flavor is sweet malt with significant hop bitterness to balance things. Must be the barrel notes that create the unusual flavor tone, perhaps this is wood, but it does not work for me. Not bad, just not one to go back to.

Im another one who had no idea what to expect. From the name, I would have expected it to sting with bitterness. But not at all. And what a delicious beer. The first thing I get is the faint aroma of Port, or Madeira. That must be from the oak barrels. Not a strong nose, no, especially for something called "Stingo". Then it pours chestnut brown, fabulously cloudy. Well, I missed to read the label instructions to pour carefully, but I love the opacity. Still, not much of a head. Coarse and mocha colour, but it wont be a minute before it disappears. Lovely sweet flavour. Malty? Yes, a bit, but honey, syrupy, yeasty and alcoholic as having a few shots of Port and a slice of Brandy-drenched fruitcake in a moist barn. Not a fan of fruitcake per-se, but in the shape of a beer it really works. I love the notes of decaying fruits and the broad finish, sweet, mellow but never overwhelming. If this is how English strong ales should be, I absolutely love it.

Pours a deep amber with a coarse tan head. Aroma is toffee, dark fruits, light coffee and nice oaky notes with some acidity. Soft body with flavors of dark fruits, toffee, oak, touches of nuttiness with creamy milk chocolate ending. No noticeable alcohol with it being 9%. Solid beer.

This is not at all what I was expecting, though since this was my first Stingo, I didnt really know what to expect.  The oak character and the dark fruit were pleasant, though the lightness of the body and appearance were off putting.  Im going to probably have to re-rate this after a second try.

Been wanting to try this for some time.  Pours reddish orange with a small off-white head.  Aroma of sauteed apples, cinnamon, toffee, golden raisin, pudding, and maybe white grape juice.  The aroma is slightly muted at first.  Flavor begins fairly sweet with toffee, brown sugar, and fruitcake/raisiny flavors, but theres a drying earthy element as well.  Finishes with earth, dirt, lingering pudding sweetness on the tongue, and yet a drying sensation on the throat.  Medium bodied and cloying in mouthfeel even though the beer doesnt come off as overly sugary to me.  Its interesting how the sweet and dry can co-exist at the same time in this beer.  Worth trying.

Cerveza envejecida en barriles de roble, un bombazo.

Tiene poca espuma al servirla, con un calor marrón rojizo, huele a frutas del bosque (mora, frambuesa), aromas dulces.

Al beberla se nota la presencia de alcohol y azúcar, sabe dulce, a caramelo, con toque de madera y no se pierden las frutas del bosque (¡como para perderse!)

Una cerveza fuerte, muy cañera, muy bien hecha.

A-- Poured a clear ruby red. One finger of light orangey brown head. Settled to a film. Decent enough lacing. Unassuming looking beer. 

S-- Soft oak, vanilla, toffee, dark fruits, apple. Great nose to this. 

T-- Red apple. Really reminds me of a cider. Soft vanilla, raisin, fig, toffee, and oak. Slightly sweet and coying. 

M-- Light carbonation and lighter medium body. More like a lower ABV barleywine or Old Ale. Quite sweet but not over the top. Fruits really carry the sweetness well. No real notes of base beer just what the oak has done to the beer. 

O-- More like drinking a pudding really. Slightly sweet but quite decadent. Slow sipper than just draws you in. Even though slightly thin the year in oak casks does wonders for the beer. Good stuff.

500ml bottle pours a dark amber color with a 2 finger off-white head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is dark fruits (raisins? figs?) with some caramel and wood.  Taste is a dark fruity and malty sweetness with some grains and mild hops and a slight alcohol in the finish.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.  A very nice English strong ale and highly recommended.

On bottle at Cerveceria Europa, Madrid- thanks Teddybeer.
Dark golden color, ok foam.
High intensity malty, dried fruits.
Medium body & medium/high complexity.
Sweetness, with balancing bitterness.
Very enjoyable

At LEurope (Madrid). Brown colour with a perfect ladting head, off-white, creamy at the beginning. Aroma is caramelish, candy sugar notes and slightly toasted malts are present. Flavour is sweet, dry fruits present with an alcoholic final. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium to high.
Bottle. The color is reddish, light tan head, and very cloudy. The smell is candy, sweet, vinous, cardboard, caramel, and nice. The taste is caramel, oxidized, watery, and ok.
Bright amber with a decent beige head. Aroma is of fruit cake, toffee, light butterscotch, raisin, oak and sherry. Taste is of toffee, caramel, bread dough, cinnamon, pound cake, and raisin.
Bottle. Clear reddish brown colour with an off-white head. Malty, but not overly sweet. Dried fruits, caramel, vanilla, oak, licorice, warming alcohol, a hint of sourness. Dry finish.
Aroma is sweet and caramelly, but with an almost cherry smell. Small head with white carbonation. Dark red/brown. Sweet taste with a bit of bitter finish.

Sweet aroma. Clear and dark brown in color. Oily and malty with smoky notes. Slightly bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Copper in color. Aroma of fruit and alcohol. Flavor was malty and also of prunes and alcohol.
Full-bodied and strong ale. Heavy aroma. Flavors of raisins and obvious treacle. There is a hint of alcohol. I should have saved this one for a cold-winter night instead of the middle of the summer.

23-JUN-2012, bottle @Ulkløbben sommerfest, @Henrik, brought by Michael.
Brown, clear with low tan head.
Sweet caramel and fruity malt with a touch of alcohol.
Too sweet for me but at least some body to it.
OK drink.

(Bottle) Amber colour with frothy, beige head. Fruity, malty nose with dried fruit, orange peel, apricots, treacle toffee and a touch of wood. Malty, fruity taste with notes of dried fruit, orange, toffee, treacle, fruitcake, a touch of wood and a gentle, slightly citric, bitterness in the finish. A slight alcohol sting as well. More than medium body, with a certain sweetness (quite well balanced though). Tasty and well balanced for its strength. Very nice beer,
22 ounce bottle from Total Wine Sac. Great taste, a little boozy. Slightly flat without much head.
Deep amber color with a thin off white head. The oak dominates the nose. Full bodied with fruity, nutty malts all over the mid palate. Low carbonation and a healthy dose of hazelnut on the finish.
fine wodden harmony with soften malt flavour little bit fruity..............

From the bottle. Pours a chestnut brown with a caramel head. Toffee, caramel and buterscotch aromas. Full bodied beer - but you cant tell its 9%. Definite oak, rasin and hevay malt flavours coming through. Sweet - great desert beer!

Bottle at home, from my Maudite glass. Pours deep caramel brown, thick cream-coloured head, sticky lacing. A sharp-looking brew! Nose is Christmas spice, red fruit, red licorice, berries, cinnamon, ginger, fig, cedar, old oak, some tea, fading/faded hops, lemongrass, very complex nose! Flavours of soft oak, some treacle/molasses notes, especially molasses, again some tea notes, with some dried berry and prune notes here as well. Oak is drying, almost tannic rather than sweet and vanillin. Overall drier than expected, and very pleasant.

I love the Yorkshire Squares!  If these guys would get crazy with their beers and experiment with Belgium yeast, various hop varieties and fruits especially Plums they could make some epic beers. Stingo really has that Jack Daniels thing working its way through it. A manly beer. Fig, plum and raisin are present. I scored this for only 3.69 at Monument! I am going to get another one of these a mix it with a spicy, fruity Belgium beer. You can taste centuries of beer making in this. The fruity aspects really are incredible. Aroma is light but flavor is strong. Mild Barleywine character. Very enjoyable. Classy beer that stand out.
Woody, fruity and spicey. This beer goes down easily and delivers hints of Christmas pudding, brandy and fruit. It does this whilst still being refreshing and light.

Bottle. Pours deep amber to brown with a small off white froth. Aroma is sweet, bready, toffee, with some caramel and dark fruit notes, a touch cakey and a hint of booze and woodiness. Flavor starts sweet with toffee and some caramel, vanilla and oak. Remains sweet and very creamy toffee candy through the finish with some dark fruit and cake lingering. Medium to medium full sticky body and a soft carbonation.

Biege head small medium carbonation rich brown pour aromas caramel dried fruit alcohol dark fruit yeast the flavours alcohol cognac raisin caramel prunes syrup rich toffee woody oak influence the finish main aftertastes dark fruit alcohol sweet maltiness bitter that sits on palate not as good as I hoped

550 mL bottle from Beers of Europe poured into a pint glass at home.  Bubbly head over a fizzy red beer.  Smells boozy, with raisin and fruit aroma.  Wow, sweet, with a slight toasted aftertaste, fruity and a bit Belgian, with a hint of vanilla.  Damned fine Yorkshire beer.

550 ml from Total Wine. Pours a murky brown with a delicate head. Medium lacing. The oak aroma comes trough strong on this. Almost a red wine on the nose, very roasty, malty. Taste of raisin, prune and very woody. Strong finish.
Dark reddish tone, yellowy head. Smells of dried fruits with woody vanilla tones. Something makes me think of sweet/sour sauce. Easy carbonation and very light bitterness.
Hazy amber,ff beige head.Lightly tart fruity,brown sugar nose.Honey sweet palate,fruity overtones,light hop finish. Mild alcohol heat

Wasnt sure what to expect as I paid so much for it (£7.50) and wasnt sure if it would live up to the price tag. Served cool but not cold (removed from the fridge for 45 mins to an hour before serving). Beautiful smell; sweet, syrupy, fruity. Got much the same from the taste. Luscious mouthfeel with a sweet yet not overpowering aftertaste. A fantastic beer - one that I would drink again in a heartbeat - although not one that I would feel comfortable paying this much for. There are better beers available for less money.
Clear orange to red colour with no head. Smells hoppy, fresh and caramel. Tastes hoppy, fresh and bitter. Medium body, good carbo.

I like Samuel Smith, but this one is not to my taste.  The pour is murky brown with a fine tan head.  No lacing.  The aroma is dark fruits and woody.  The taste is oak and fruit with a very dry finish.  Simply not my style.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fruity, citrusy up front followed by a crisp finish. Very nice. Good "early" drink to be followed by something darker.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
5oz pour.  Thin palate.  Very sweet taste.  Aroma just isnt there.  This looks like sewer water but had a nice head on it.  Not bad, just not that memorable either

Dark fruits and rum like sweetness predominate on the nose helped along by the gentle carbonation. There is also a distinct Port quality to the nose to my mind. The taste is a rich, with a smooth, raisin flavour and surprisingly dry character. The finish has a nice heat from the alcohol. This is a nicely balanced beer, which has a rather gentle charm.
Color oscuro algo rojizo con cabeza media de espuma blanca. Olor intenso a caramelo y malta. Sabor dulce con un regusto final amargo. Muy buena cerveza.

Pours murky brown with a small ring of light tan, khaki fizz. Smells sweet, oaky, with a nice vanilla characteristic, coupled with some caramel and dark fruit aromas. Taste is sweet, smooth caramel and vanilla flavors that waltz with some dark fruit, raisin, plum, fig, flavors. Medium to full bodied with a smooth, velvety texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Sam Smith Yorkshire Stingo finishes with some smooth sweetness that is reminiscent of vanilla.

The wholesome red-brown of a conker. The nose is layer upon later of fruit with light wooded undertones. Sweet and deeply fruity with just a touch of heat to it, the aging really shines through. There is enough mild dryness to stop it becoming to cloying. It has a wonderfully luscious body, thick and smooth. There are heaps of dried cherry glaciers with some sweeter marzipan playing a part too. Hints of lightly chocolate malt. A very finely crafted brew.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Deep brackish red-brown body.  Moderate sized khaki head, decent retention, minimal lacing.

S: Caramel, raisins, toffee, nuts, and that nice Samuel Smith twang.

T: Takes a step back in terms of complexity, but a step forward in intensity.  Toffee and caramel dominate the initial burst of flavor.  Rounded out by raisins and a mellow boozyness.  

M: Medium-full bodied.  Smooth carbonation, light boozyness and bitterness.

O: A solid beer that capitalizes on some of the flavors that Sam Smith does best.
Bottle with Carla. Pours a hazy caramel-brown with light tan foam. Smells sweet of alohol, oak, caramel and molases. Tastes sweet with hints of raison, plum, caramel, and grapefruit and alcohol.

Bottle. Deep ruby brown color with a tan head that settles. The nose is fruity - some cherries, chestnuts, brown sugar, a bit of port. The taste is quite fruity, sweet, witha slightly alcoholic acidic finish. Plenty o malt flavor. Medium/full body. A bit sticky. Light carbonation. Overall, quite nice, but theres obviously better at this price point...

Blonde-amber pour into thick beige head that slowly dissipates into a pool of swirling foam and a ring of melting bubbles. Aroma of tart cherry, smoky oak, and dark roasted chocolate. Initial flavor of sweet citrus, roasted caramel, tart cherry syrup, and dark chocolate that slowly fades into a peppery, malty finish.

Poured 550 ml into a pint glass.  it had barnyard aroma with delicate hints of goat feed.  It had a rich amber color with a llite carbonation.  With carmel and currant favors. Very little oak favors, lots of floaters.  Younger barrels might make this a awesome beer.

Brewed in 2009
Tasted on 1/26/12 from a 550mL bottle purchased at Binnys Lincoln Park.  Pours clear, but dark auburn, with an average tan head that slowly recedes to a thick collar of lace.  The nose is lightly spiced caramel, with some hints of cinnamon, vanilla, golden raisin, and maple.  The flavor is pretty sweet with maple, caramel, and vanilla up front, moving to the cinnamon and baking spices, with just a hint of some bitterness and the golden raisin showing an almost vinous note.  The body is full with lively carbonation and a long, lightly bitter, vinous golden raisin finish.
Been looking forward to this beer for a long time now and it didnt disappoint. Aromas of malt, hay. Tastes of super malty, vanilla. Overall a great beer.

Bottle: Brown color, light beige head. Aroma is fruity, notes of cherries, berries and plums. Chocolate and malt. Flavor is medium malty, quite fruity (plums), roasted malt, oak barrles, alcohol, dark chocolate, cacao. Roasty and light hoppy bitterness in the end. Nice.
Bottle care of Chuwy. Slightly oxidized aroma, green apples, caramel. Big green apples in the mouth, too big, with caramel and minerals. Smooth and silky, but disappointing as I was expecting a lot.

Bottle
Appearance - Deep cherry red, bubbly, thick head
Aromas - Oak, earthy, hops, caramel
Taste - Dried citrus, cherries, toffee, alcohol

2009 "vintage bottle". This may be my first oak-aged English strong ale. The oak presence was nice and pleasant, adding a nice and dry undertone to the fruity presence. While aromas were spicy and full of mellow earthy tones - the flavor was still much more fruity then I would expect. This made for a smooth and mellow aftertaste, which was very nice given the higher ABV.
amber red color. Wet cardbord, creamy, green apples. I dont think the bottle I had was in the best condition.

A clear dark red/brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of dark fruits with a little wood notes and dark malts. The taste is of bitter fruits with laurel. There are hints of wood, some sweet notes. A little burny. The aftertaste is sweet, bitter with a little alcohol.

Bottle. Another classic from England up for rating; excited about this one! :-) Pours a deep hazy rose-hued brown-orange body with a small white head. Nose is wood, vanilla, caramel, hints of hibiscus and dusty biscuits. Taste is hibiscus, pale malts, citrus and syrupy notes with vanilla, oak and dry hops. Very original and and hard to pin down. DIPA? BW? ESA? Seems to have a lot from all these genres. Awesome, regardless. :-)

Een bijzonder koninklijke Ale. Het aroma doet onmiskenbaar denken aan de typical English ale. Een ongewoon hoog alcoholpercentage voor een Brits bier. Donker fruit is duidelijk aanwezig, met name rozijnen. Past heerlijk bij blauwe kaas.

Pours a pretty red/orange color.  Aroma has a tiny hint of spirits to it.  Getting a lot of raisin and a bit of caramel.  The finish is a little weak.  The base cannot hold up the start of the beer.  Not much oak at all to me.

Aroma starts with metallic carbonate twang, but that disppears as the thick tan head reduces. What is left is a dark fruit smell. The taste is nice and complex; raisin, burnt sugar, maybe even a bit of smoke. Sweet hit is balanced by a nice peppery hop taste. Vinious elements finish, like a fortified wine, which warms. Expensive, but good.
bottle. The smell is pretty typical of that of an english ale.  The taste is very carbonated with a decent amount going on.  Nice and smooth though.  Finishes clean and refreshing.  Would have again.

Pours dark amber with a quick light brown head and decent but fine lacing. Nose is brown sugar, caramel, wood, and some alcohol. Flavor is surprisingly weak, with only hints of the above tones and a touch of hops....backside is watery. Maybe English ales are supposed to be boring, but Im not English and I dont like boring.

2010  bottled  raisiny malty aroma  - enticing  . pours with a small beige head  with just traces remaining . lovely clear copper/ amber colour .  caramelly malty treacly semi sweet taste  balanced by medium carbonation  with a dryer slightly hoppy finish .Succulent . Moreish . alcohol warnth comes through at the end but does not intrude into the taste . Easily in my top ten

Bottle pours a big manilla white head.  The nose is of toffee, plum, maybe even raison, definitely fruity.  Appearance is a light brown or deep amber when held up to the light.  There is a smoothness to this beer that it is hard to find in most American brews up to the 9% mark.  The taste comes on as fruity and slightly sweet.  The follow up is slightly warm from the alcohol and a bit dry and woody from the aging process.  The complex malt flavors and the warming alcohol slightly reminds me of a Belgian Dubbel.  I could fall in love with this beer.

Pour is a murky brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit, molasses and sugar.  Flavor is some dark fruit, toffee and oak.  After the swallow you get more of an oak and wine like quality.  Finish leaves some vanilla and raisin.  A really expensive bottle but Im glad I got to try it.  A x-mas preasent for myself

Bottle from Scott for my 34th. Aroma is of caramel and candy sugar. Pours with little to no head. Flavor is of caramel, malt, light sugar, and grassy hops. Very good in palate and appearance. Great beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Translucent redish mahogany with a thin but persistant beige head. Full body with medium carbonation.

Aroma: sweet treacle, toffee, oblaten fruit cake, doppelbock maltiness.

Taste: same. Rich and complex, with a definite aged character. Somewhat cloying.

Bottle.
Deep brown pour with a creamy off-white head.  Nose of oak, caramel, and toffee - taste is slightly woody and earthy with raisin, toffee, and caramel.  Way too expensive for what it is but still tasty.
Rich and heavy with vanilla on the nose. Thick body with fizzy carbonation and plenty of malt character.

Found a bottle of this luckily. Pours a bright reddish color with a solid white head. Aroma was of vanilla, oak, and ripe fruit. The extensive aging process this beer has undergo made it very mellow. Sweet fruits, smoky oak, vanilla, and slight hoppiness. Mouth feel was a touch thin possibly from the age of the beer. Not bad, but doesnt stand out. Way over priced.

aroma - gummy, fruit and sweet. funny smell similar to innis and gunn, possibly the wood.
appearance - cloudy murky walnut
taste - banana bread, nuts, plum, white raisin 
palate - full body but has some sparkle
Drank a treat and I wouldnt really have picked it as a higher alcohol beer, taste is very smooth and full in body, dried fruit notes along with vanilla and some banana .

Bottle. Pours a somewhat hazy copper with creamy beige head. Aroma has fruit esters, slight must, very subtle hints of farmhouse with the faintest touch of toffee. Flavor is similar with some off-flavor notes that blend nicely when it us all said and done, nice malt backbone, yeast, fruit, alcohol spice with the slightest hint of oak. Mouthfeel is medium body, lightly silky, with soft carbonation. Overall, after a few sips it becomes pretty relaxing and enjoyable.

Murky amber/orange with a thin head. Oak and raisins are definitely present in the aroma. Malt and orange fruit make up the sweet body. Really thought there would be more flavors hidden in the palate, but nothing stands out. Mild earthy bitterness. Its ok.

500ml Bottle, Rehills, Ncl. I was surprised that this wasnt a lot darker, but its a really nice looking deep red beer. Christmas cake aroma, but I thought it might have a bit more to it. However, it tastes beautifully mellow, has enough warming subtleness, which becomes more apparent on the swallow. Lovely sweetness, but its not overpowering. Put this off a few times, on the grounds of price, but worth the wait. (£4.99, on offer)

550mL bottle.  Amber color.  Vinous aroma.  Flavor is light, mellowed from the oak.  Mild touch of fruit, toffee, caramel.  Oh so mild.  A bit pricey.  Enjoyable to drink.  A bit too much for my wallet.
550 ml bottle pour.  Amberish color.  Nice lacing.  Light white head.   Malty nose.  Oak ale casks mellow the beer nice.  Well done.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a lightly hazy orange / brown with a very fine white ring of head. Aroma of strawberries, cherries, apricots, candied sugar, molasses, wood and licorice. Flavour of liqueur, summer fruits, candied sugar, molasses and butterscotch. Palate is surprisingly full bodied compared to what I expected. Nicely balanced. Go England! Fuck the flag.

Bottle. Pours a rare muddy Red with a thin beige head. Wonderful nose. Woody. Reminiscent briefly of an oaked Chardonnay. Lots of dried fruity flavour. Syrupy prunes. The alcohol is not well conceale. Leaves a not unpleasant warmth. Sweet and warming. A delicious beer.
Bottle I brought to Zieke Zuiden Tasting II. Nice red color, small white head. Smell wood, alcohol, lightly sweet. Taste decent sweetness, alcohol and wood again. Decent carbonation, medium body.

Bottle @ ZZT11 #2: Thanks to Benzai:
Small, quick disappearing white head on top of a clear dark ruby colored beer.
Smell barleys, toasted malts, some spices/herbs.
Taste barleys, malts, corn, hops, honey, medium bitter.
Nice bitter malty barleys aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a creamy texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Appearance: clear and deep, red-orange-gold, short creamy head.   Aroma:  buttery toast, caramel, prunes, figs and raisins.  Taste: lightly toasted malts, date cake, a note of baklava, some vanilla, oak, and caramel.   Finish:  smooth, balanced, a little fruity and just a hint of booze. Notes:Not at all what I expected, but enjoyable nonetheless.  Very fruity but not over-sweet, with some nice spiciness.  Reminiscent of a Belgian strong ale.  Glad I got achance to try it.

Bottle poured into snifter.  Unique murky reddish brown color with a substantial soapy head.  Complex and appealing aroma of slight coffee and chocolate, oak, leather, molasses, burnt toffee.  Earthy, roasty in flavor with notes of fig, raisin, other dark fruits.  Sticky, bittersweet finish.  Interesting, strong all-around beer.

550mL bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours a mostly clear copper/ amber with a tiny, quickly dissipating head. Aroma of caramel, English malts, butterscotch, apple, plum and other dark fruits. Flavour is quite rich, with rich toffee / caramel, butterscotch, plum, other dark fruits and berries. Full-bodied, oily texture. Most excellent - great example of the style.

Poured from bottle into Samuel Smith pint.

Pours a very cloudy rusty brown. A small 1/2 inch head remains throughout. No lacing.

Smells quite like a whisky. Lots of oak with a little vanilla. A small amount of malt and dark fruit.

Taste is very smooth with oak and vanilla up front followed by some dark fruits. There is a lingering sourness throughout but not to the point of being overbearing. The alcohol is extremely well-hidden.

Overall this is a good, complex beer. I enjoyed reading about the production and extensive aging but at $10.99 per bottle, Im not sure how often I will be revisiting it.

I pour the beer into my nonic pint and it arrives in the glass a very deep red color.  A very thin and bubbly head sits on top of the liquid for just a few seconds before it is gone.  Im kind of lucky to have gotten the picture of it.

The nose just punches you in the face.  Lots of cherries and other dark fruits.  You get a distinct character of vanilla and oak.  Then the alcohol subtly stings the nostrils.

The taste follows suit with a complex taste.  More dark fruit upfront that turns earthy.  Follow this up with more oak quality and a very warming alcohol taste.  The alcohol becomes even more apparent as it warms up.  It kind of reminds me of a brandy or Scotch at points.

Finally full use of my20 oz SS English Pub glass.It all fit with 1/2 inch of head.Murky brownish red. Lots of carmel malt aroma,barelywineish,mild english,some vanilla and some dark fruit..Same in flavor with fruit like mellow  hops with a good finish of mild smooth dark bitter,a little chaulky on the finish.This is fairly syrupy with not alot of complexity,You get the oak sweet caramel malt english and mild fruit,but overall it seems bland until you get the bitter in the finish leaving a decent hop bittering that lingers a little.Not worth the price it is. Maybe this could use cellering or something,but at the price i paid-not too impressed. After making my own  oaked english strong ale i thought was bland its pretty comparable to this,and not shure which i thought was better,probably this because the bittering is decent.Its just a kind of bland carmely sweet beer.I guess it is english/comparing it to american strong ales i just think more hop flavor gives strong ales better character to match up the carmel sweetness.
I also failed to leave the yeast,so maybe ill have to re-rate this again.Maybe refrigerating longer also.

Pour is amber and clear with a thin and small off white head...smell is toasty and sweet with some booze and strong oak notes...taste is sweet with prunes and raisins up front with strong woody flavors too...twinge of bitterness and moderate heat from booze...well done and enjoyable.

Light brown full lasting creamy head. Brown-dark copper colour. Aroma is malty with fruity, raisins, light toffee, wooden and alcohol notes, Flavor is malty too with toffee, caramel and fruity (raisins) tones, ending in a moderately fruity and slightly wooden finish. Full bodied.
Redish amber with medium, off-white head. Fruity with wood notes. Malt, hops, fruit and wood. full body with a long, bitter sweet finish.

Bottle. Pours a very nice mahogany red/brown. Sweet malty caramel aroma. Deep taste. Lots of caramel malt, moves into a nice balance of oak, dried fruits, light spices. Sweet on the palate. Very good indeed
Poured copper with thin head smelled of raisins cold with oaken smell coming after it warmed tasted plain but very drinkable good beer

Sampled atban esbls tasting. Na hig off white head.  Cloudy and brown.  A nice fruity and malty aroma with honey and raisins.  The flavor is nice but does not stand up to the nose. Nraisins are a strong theme in the flavor.  It is hot from alcohol.  This is tasty but too hot.

Cloudy reddish amber pour thin off white head that did not last long at all ..... aroma of caramel malts, and fruits raisins ..... taste is of caramel malts and toffee with a dry oak and a nice fruity flavor of raisin mostly .... the dry oak flows into the finish with toffee and a bitter hop punch and some warming abv .... well done a very smooth and tasty brew
Black of color with a beige head. An aroma of prunes, liqurice, roasted and sweets. A flavor of  sweets, liqurice, bitter and dark fruits.

Bottle. Pours a rich red-brown with a creamy head. Nose is oaky with elements of vanilla, brown sugar, and dried fruit. Flavor is very rich, with an interplay of spice, sweetness, and soy sauce/black bean sauce notes. Mouthfeel is rich and very round, sumptuous, with a long, dark finish. Lovely.

very biscuity aroma with dried fruit and a bit of oak. toffee and vanilla as well. pours  a sort of blurry dark orange-brown with small rocky tan head. its dry and flat and slightly on the sweet side, caramelly. thin and dry for a 9% with a sweet oaky finish. this is pretty tasty, and gets better when warmed, with

En old ale på stadiga 9%. Snygg etikett, vacker djup bärnstensfärgad vätska. Litet skumlock. Söta maltiga dofter av äppelmos och kanderat socker. Smaken är mycket varmt intensiv av alkoholen, maltigt söt åt marsipan, ekfaten känns i botten och en lång eftersmak av marsipan med bittermandel. Ett stort och mycket gott öl som nog mått bra av ett år till i källaren men som var mycket njutbart redan nu. Snygg retroetikett.
Dark amber colored brew. Sweet malty aroma. Flavor has sweet malts, boozy, some roast and dark fruits.
2010 bottle:  Pours a clear orange with a medium off-white head, aroma has oranges, light grains and caramel, medium bodied, starts and ends lightly sweet with a woody ending.

To begin, the bottle has a quite look to it which is quiet nice. The aroma of it is quite complex but you can definitely smell some toffee. The taste is delicious, if not one of the bests the best Samuel Smiths beer yet!
Brown with a good head.  Taste is a twangy malt - roasted flavors.  Some alcohol really comes through as it works.

Bottle from kegs and barrels.  Pours a rich dark amber with a thin off white head.  The aromas are bourbon, vanilla and yellow cake.  The mouthfeel is slightly sticky, warm and has a mediu-heavy body.  Thus was a great beer!

Dark amber/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, oak, caramel, & fruit; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, caramel/toffee, dark fruit, raisons, and some hops; Finish is slight tart/sour; Nicely balanced; Overall, solid English ale.

Bottle 55 cl, Kris Wines, London. Pours clear dark orange amber with a good beige head leaving pretty lacing. Aroma is fruity, malty, caramel, raisins and slightly yeasty; like a Xmas cake. Fullbodied sweet fruity mouthfeel. Flavor is lots of fruits - like bananas and apricots - malty, slightly bitter hoppy and caramel. Oddly the 9 % ABV doesnt appear as strong as I had expected. Finishes sweet malty with some bitter pungeant aftertaste.
Bottle. Pours dark brown. Tan head. Nose/taste of plum, toffee, oak, date pits and sweet caramel. Sweet mouth feel. Well balanced. Medium body.

550 ml bottle, from Voldby Købmandsgård, Denmark. 2009 brew, BB June 2012. ABV is 9%. Copper to chestnut coloured beer, large off-white head. Strong sweetish malty and vinous aroma, notes of raisins, caramel and oak. The flavour is also malty, oaky and vinous, with notes of old sherry, treacle and raisins, tolerable hops in the finish. Harmonious, elegant and very enjoyable..

Poured a bubbly orange amber hue with a light tan head that faded quickly.  Aroma consisted of Vanilla, oak, caramel malts and dried fruits. Flavor was initially sweet.  A nice balance between caramel malts and dried fruits after taste was of vanilla and a warming alcohol presence. Somewhat syrupy on the palate.  An appropriate amount of carbonation.
Pours a lovely orange color, with aroma notes of orange, raisins, and nuts. Toffee, raisin, orange almost resinous. Taste of oak and malt, with a sour kick.
Clear dark orange with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and fruity. Flavor is quite sweet. Dry finish with a little warming alcohol. Soft. 130611
