Brown, beige head, good lace. Sweet, toffee, nuts, malty, raisin, laurel in the finish. Alcohol well hidden, sticky, full, cloying even. Flavourful, balanced and easy.

Aroma is full and fruity with some spices, strawberry, caramel, syrup, malt and sugar. Also a bit of oak. Taste is quite strong with oak, malt syrup and vanilla. Quite sweet with a nicely dry and bitter end.

550ml bottle, code SG07J1, bottled July 7, 2010.  Picked up on discount at $6.99.  Served at cellar temperature.
Pours red/brown with a one finger light beige head that recedes to a foamy island and ring leaving a few spots of lacing behind.

Aroma is strong and complex and features rich raisins and dates, figs, plums, cherries and other fruits, plenty of oak and vanilla, caramel, toffee and bread, culminating as what I can best describe as a "creamy" and sweet aroma.  Very inviting.

Flavor is also full of dark fruits, dark raisins, dates, figs, plums, cherries, a lot of toffee and caramel, some chocolate, a bit of earthy hops and some noticeable alcohol warmth on the finish.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied and starts creamy but that is quickly wiped away by some strong scrubbing carbonation.

This is one I have eyeballed for quite some time but the normal $11 price tag always kept me away.  However, as soon as it went on sale I had to pick up at least one and now that Ive tried this delicious brew, Ill be back for more.

Bottle (vintage 2009): Hazy, deep amber coloured, stable small to medium-sized tanned head; rich and complex nose: x-mas cake, fruits and dried fruits, caramel, nuts and sprinkels of cacao; very solid sweet-bitter flavour with a light tannic acidity, nearly full bodied; lingering caramelly and fruity finish, rounded by hops and cacao in the aftertaste. Yes, they can..........

"Brewed in 2008."  550 ml bottle purchased in early 2010 at Holiday Wine Cellar ($11.69).  Pours a muddy red with two fingers of light beige foam.  Aroma of caramel, raisin, cherry, oak, and some vanilla.  Flavor includes sweet dark toffee, holiday spiced fruits, and some dry oakiness.  Sweet but not quite cloying.  Syrupy mouthfeel with well-concealed alcohol.  Quite good for the style.  (321, 525)
As far as appearance this brew is lovely. It kinda of reminded me of  Orval. Very fizzy and and astringent finish.

A brownish/copper color that was cloudy and hazy.  Orange highlights abound at the bottom of the glass.  An off white, mostly creamy, smooth head with nice size and above average retention with an easy pour.  Adequate lacing is left behind.  A malt dominated nose with characteristics of dried, dark fruits.  The "woody" aroma is very pleasant and fits in perfectly.  I got a dried apple chip type smell in there also.  Sweet!!!  It does kind of smell Christmas"y" with the dried fruits.  With the taste, I once again obtained the dried, dark fruit along with a Bourbon flavoring mixed with the "woody" tones.  Malty tones that seem to be somewhat toasted.  Some relaxed flavors of caramel and toffee.  Well balanced.  Rather sweet tasting.  Medium to medium/full mouthfeel.  Chewy, dry and smooth.  Some welcome alcohol warmth teetering on a slight burn at the back of the throat.  Covers the palate justly until the next sip.  Another solid effort from the Sam Smiths  A very enjoyable beer.  One for sipping.  It filled me up, so the drinkability is not as high as some others from the brewery.  Rather sweet also.  I would have it again with ease, but its not a brew I would want on a regular basis.  A  few time a year would be nice though.  Worth a try if you come across it.

(bottle, 55cl, vintage 2009) Hazy, chestnut-brown colour with a tanned medium-sized foamy head. Sweet and slightly yeasty toast-malty aroma with raisiny and vinous fruity notes, accompanied by a touch of vanilla and woody hops. Sweet and delicately bitter flavour, full bodied with a very smooth, almost silky carbonation. Complex malt-character with notes of caramel, cacao, christmas pudding and dried fruits; sweet, delicately bitter and tannic finish with vinous fruity notes and a lingering aftertaste with chocolate. Recommended. 06.IV.11

550 ml bottle. Finland.
Dark hazy amber colour with small off-white head.
Very mild aroma of berries and sugar.
Flavour is also mild. Malt, alcohol and some Bock-y flavours. Fizzy.
Im not convinced.
Sweet malt aroma with a light amount of hops. Cloud brown color with a medium tan head. Moderate bitter beginning that quickly turns sweet until fading in the end.
55cl, Vintage 2009, at 9%Vol, exclusive English brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, complex brew, not too heavy, balanced, hazy, good head, good brew, yet expensive

Bottle, shared with Jeff. Medium red-orange amber, medium off white head. Aroma is reminiscent of mince meat Christmas tarts-- heaps of sweet raisins, underlying brown sugar and vanilla, and a rummy/boozy quality. Flavours follow the nose, with dried raisin and plum fruit and caramel malt, some spicy vanilla oak, a a dry woodiness in the finish. Somewhat like a tawny port, only less sweet with a medium body. Very nice.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Bottled. 
Burgundy colour with beige head. Oxidized aroma, with vanilla and dark dried fruits, like plums or the likes. Higher alcohols and a dash of milk. Flavourwise also clear in oxidation - raisins, sweet malt, rich flavour. Bit of vanilla. A massive raisin feel comes late. Long flavour. Medium body with low bitterness.

Sampled from an 18.7 oz brown bottle this beer poured a murky brown color with orange highlights and a medium sized creamy tan head that lingered and left some lacing. The aroma was tart and tangy with light notes of lemon, grapefruit, caramel and cherry. The flavor was tart and tangy with moderate notes of caramel, cherry, sugar, chocolate and a bit of nut. The finish was long with lingering toffee, chocolate and fruit. Moderately full bodied. Very nice.
Bottle from Burg Bieren. Amber colour, off-white head. Aroma is caramel malts and spicy, and lots of hops. Flavour is caramel malts, hoppy and spicy. Excellent stuff.

A vigorous pour into my Lost Abbey Teku glass produces a three finger thick, pale amber tinged, tan colored head.  The beer is a dark amber color and, strikingly enough, when held up to the light it is quite hazy and has the same orange-red hue of ruby-red grapefruit juice.  The aroma smells of buttery, vanilla laden oak backed by umami notes that hint at rich aged malt (oxidized, nutty and like a dry sherry).  The nose doesnt smell like it has much sweetness to it.  There even seems to be a touch of tartness to the nose.  The nuttiness seems to accentuate a dry, toasted maltiness, though this is fairly subtle.  I dont know what I was expecting from this beer, but the nose is completely different from what I was expecting.

Somewhat light bodied, quite dry and a bit colder than I would prefer.  The beer finishes with a rich, nutty, sherry-like character that lingers on the palate after my first sip.  There is a hint of bitterness in the finish as well as a touch of spiciness (that might be derived from the oak influence).  There is a soft, quite oxidized, toasted maltiness here as well as a spicy flavor that reminds me of Bourbon (the oak influence no doubt).  As the beer warms up a sweet, caramelized note starts to pick up a bit and interacts with the oak to boost a vanillin note in the flavor.  I do like the relatively light texture and body that this beer has, though it is at the expense of a malt richness that could help add some balance to this beer.

Interesting, but not quite where I would have liked.  It could actually use more rich malt character here as the oak really seems to dominate the flavor a bit more than I would prefer.  Not bad, and certainly worth finishing if you are happy with just having a beer; and it is not like this doesnt have some interesting flavors in it though.
Bottle. Hazy amber/orange with medum off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, sweet, alcohol and oak.
Medium brown with a fizzy white head.  Chocolate, toffee, vanilla, oak and strong grain aroma and taste.

A: The beer pours a copper sort of color with a thin ring of off-white foam--theres no real head to speak of.

S: Smells quite sweet. Lots of white and brown sugar notes to start. Seems to be some toffee and a lot of sherry notes (including alcohol). I get some miscellaneous fruits, but raisins in particular.

T: Quite a lot of fruit on the palate. I get pears, apples, and raisins for the most part. Again, a strong sugar presence with brown sugar, toffee, and caramel. The oak is well represented and there is a definite alcohol flavor.

M: Medium in both body and carbonation.

D: Not sure why this one is so talked up, I thought it was pretty mediocre.

Aroma: not too strong, more woody/malty than fruity/sugary; Appearance: thick, bubbly, creamy, tan head on pour that lingers for a bit but eventually mostly dissipates except for a ring of foam around the perimeter of the glass, hazy, though not quite opaque, mix between brown and red, like a burnt sienna (there, I used that crazy crayon color); Taste: fantastic, absolutely fantastic, initial swallow is caramel, mixed with strong fig (rather than raisen), and maybe a little bit of red apple (even though the dont mention apple on the bottles label), Id have to say, for me, the oak/wood aspect is more in the aroma than the taste, this is really, really good; Palate: honestly, the palate is what I think Ill remember most about this beer, it is the perfect consistency, if I can describe a beer as such, creamy, but not Guiness creamy, and, seriously, the perfect balance of carbonation, any more or less would significantly compromise my enjoyment of this beer, just a nice sweet, yeasty flavor that lingers in the perfect way; Overall: I will definately be buying the beer again, especially since I was supposed to share the one Im drinking now with my Dad last time he came to visit (we were busy enjoying other stuff, so we didnt get around to this one)

aroma- caramel, toffee, oak, dark fruit, cherry, vanilla, chocolate, cream, pudding, bread, spice.  pours hazy red brown.  taste is oak, bread, caramel, chocolate, rich toffee, cereal, dark fruit.  palate is rich, smooth, and velvety.

18.7 oz bottle into English pint, shared with Brenn79. Thanks! 2009 bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange with a nice-sized light beige head. Has a malty, fruity aroma--orange peels? Some caramel in there, raisin bread. Taste is sweet and sour with just a touch of bitterness. Kind of has an old taste to it. Since its aged in up to 100 year old casks, maybe thats to be expected? Palate is both creamy and sticky. Carbonation is low to medium, but not to the detriment of the beer. Nice.

550 ml. bottle- Pours deep orangeish red with a nice off white head, aroma is sweet malt, citrus and cherries or  berries of some sort. The flavor is malty in a good way (not too heavy) with cherry flavors and a nice mellow oaky backbone. Medium high carbonation, creamy full flavored, and an oaky finish. Good beer.

medium red with large white head that quickly dissipates.  nose of medium crystal malt with a touch of alcohol and some sherry-like notes.  low carbonation before mild bitterness.  medium crystal with some low crystal notes predominate before some vanilla and a touch of oak.  the alcohol is present and provides some distraction.  the residual sweetness is quite low for the style.  if this beer aged a few years and allowed the alcohol to diminish it would likely improve somewhat, but the oak would likely go with it as well.  overall, a nice english-style old ale, but not overly remarkable

At first glance and based on aroma, thought it was going to be similar to a barleywine.  Very complex fruity flavor and warming alcoholic punch to it, but for such a high price, it could have been better and could have lived without the the oak (?) flakes stuck to the bottom.

Bottle at home.
Clear dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel, dark fruit and oak). Flavor moderate+ sweet, moderate bitter, in good balance. Medium to full body, soft carbonated, the alcohol warms. Really fine.
0.55l - Bread dough nose, nice head, cloudy orange color.  Palate was stone fruit with noticeable boozy signature.  Put this in a 750 and I would have thought it Belgian.

9th March 2009  Clear dark brown beer, good biscuit head. A complex brew. Soft creamy frothy start. Toffeeish malt seamlessly blended with spciy hop. A touch of oaky sweetness. A trace of bubblegum in the semi dry finish. Really well joined up classic English beer!

Bottle 550 ml from Bier-Bienne (CH). Reddish-brown veiled, fine and off-white foam. Flavors of toffy, oak, malted biscuit, dried fruits and toast. The taste is soft of toffy-molasses, maple syrup, raisin, barley sugar, apricot, woody and earthy hints. Creamy with nuts and Xeres, touch of grassy hop in final. Worth a visit.
great beer, just way too darn expensive for what you get; howover truly enjoyable and pairs well with several different foods.

Bottle from Vas Foremost. Pours a ruddy and hazy ruby with offwhite head. Looks like a wood-aged Old Ale. Nose is pretty solid. Strongly hopped with EKG being the predominant hop note. Oak, Simpsons Golden Syrup, plum and maple. Quite fruity, but thats the SS character for you. On taste, slight tartness, more of the oaky vanilla notes and strong raisin character. Alcohol is present as well. A bit thin bodied and a touch tinny. Still, Pretty solid beer and the best Ive had from Sam Smith, most likely.

Bottled late 2009 - early 2010? Amber with a large, creamy tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma: vanilla, dried fruits, some type of red candy (Ferrari, Zoo?), some licorice, sweet and malty. Taste: sweet licorice, dried fruits, raisins, toffee, malty and medium bitter, fruit, perhaps wine gums, not exactly port, but something similar. Full bodied with some carbonation in the mouthfeel. Really nice this one.

Brewed in 2009, bottled in 2010, drank in 2011.

Beer was recommended to me by BA Kendo.

Poured into my Dogfish Head oversized snifter. First pour roused a decent inch or so khaki tinted foam, not much staying power very little lacing to speak.  Beer is a hazy copper to light amber in color.

Aroma gives wafts of cherry, dates and plum right upfront.  Then a lot of powdery malt, moss, earthiness.  If you have ever poured boiling or near boiling liquid on slate or stone you know it creates a very tangible aroma, this beer carries that.  So touches of chocolate and tart sour fruit in the back. So port wine and belgian dark ale aroma as it warms.  Very complex and rich.  A bit of cognac with a good swirl as it warms as well.

A surprising bitterness and apparent carbonation upfront, tart cherries, raisin and bittersweet cocoa in the middle with a souring tart and very oaky tannin finish.  There is caramel and toffee upfront too with some touches of grape and a bit of a grassy/hay tone (English Brett?)

This beer has mouthfeel in spades, luscious depth, medium full bodied, oaky tannins that blend with tart characteristics and sweet caramel malts, finishes semi-sweet but balanced with carbonation, alcohol and tannins.

Absurdly drinkable for the 9% abv with loads of character and depth.  There should be three in your beer cellar to surprise the next three guests in your home who have not tried this beer yet.

Caramel with good, creamy, tan head / Nose of brown sugar and cooked fruit / Medium to full body, some chewiness, gentle carbonation, malty with hint of sweetness, but good, dry, finish /  Musty flavors of molasses, brown sugar, nuts, dates, gingerbread, and oak / Very nice.  A beer seemingly greater than the sum of its parts, perhaps due to the especially fine body.

Cloudy brown with a fine tan head that keeps at a 1/4 inch thick. Slightly roasty aroma with cherries, vanilla, sawdust, bread, nuts, mellow alcohol, and the slightest hint of English hops. The flavor is strong, with a nice blend of dark fruit, toffee, wheat bread, vanilla, and wood. Pretty sweet overall, with a bit of bitter balancing on the finish. Very full, almost chewy body with both soft and prickly carbonation and a bit of alcohol warming in the back of the throat. Woody vanilla notes linger a while. Well crafted and very complex.

550 ml. bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with a small biege head.  Aroma of caramel, dark fruit and malt.  Taste is very complex.  Lots of dark fruit, caramel and some alcohol.  Warming.  Very nice.
Pours a deep garnet color with a medium sized foamy off white head. Notes of car wash sponge, werthers candies, cardamom pods, vanilla, raisins, and vinyl. Just ok.

Chestnut brown color with a creamy off-white head.  Dark fruit, vanilla, and wood aromas with caramel, dark fruit, oak, and a touch of alcohol flavors.  Thick and creamy body.  Good lacing.  Slow sipper.  Good beer.

Bottle from West Lakeview Liquors.  Tasted 12/25/2010.  Pours a hazy, reddish-brown with a tan head.  Aroma is fruity and malty.  Heavy on the palate with a lot of carbonation.  Flavor is malty, yeast, sweet, and oaky.  A very good, complex beer.

Pours mahogany with amber highlights.  Aroma is heavy on the malt, with biscuit notes prevailing.  Rich caramel and chocolate notes provide a great full bodied backbone that plays well with light English hopping.  Nice brew

This beer pours a murky dark brownish-amber color with a medium light tan head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Dark fruit, vanilla, and oak in the nose. Medium body with flavors of caramel malt, dark fruit, oak and a bit of booze. The finish is toasted malt and fruit with an oaky aftertaste. Pretty good overall, but did not blow me away as the Draft magazine score of 100 suggested.

Light brown red colour. Usually ale type of head, and smell is quite traditional e.g. hops and sourness is expected. And thats whats delivered. There is also some blunt earthly aromas, almost basement. I also found citrus and bit of flower. Rather OK beer.

Pours a hazy copper with fluffy but thin tan head.  Aroma is heavy on the raisin and malt, maybe a touch of caramel.  Toffee sweetness to start, a touch of oak and bittering hops rounds out the middle, and it finishes out with a nice bitter balanced by dark fruits.  Fairly sticky. thick, and a touch boozy, but goes down nicely.  Overall a very good beer

Medium cloudy brown with touch of red, medium head.  Aroma is strong, dried fruit, figs, raisins, etc with some caramel.  Medium full body with slight alcohol and some carbonation.  Flavor is pretty sweet with the same dried fruits, brown sugar, banana.  Not as much oak as I would have expected from the description.  Just enough bitterness and the carbonation and a little acidity prevents it from being too sticky.  Would definitely have it again.

[500ml bottle, The Bottle, York] Deep red colour with a fair amount of swirly chunks in the bottom. No head to speak of. Aromas of sherry, prunes, raisins and caramel malts. Quite syrupy sweet, but it pulls back before it reaches the cloying state. Surprisingly drinkable  long sweet finish, hint of toffee and butterscotch before the more evident spirit flavours from the cask aging [25112010]

Bottle - listed as 9%, for reference; Pour is cloudy dark golden amber with an average off white head ; nice retention on this one. Nice fruitiness on the nose ; dark fruits and a hint of apple, I suppose. I enjoyed the toffee, apples, and dark fruits , but I have to say I didnt really get an oak feel from this brew as it is stated.  Yeast sediment is present here and clouds the glass -  There is a hint of spice - overall, very excellent.

THOUGHTS: Not at all what I was expecting, but not bad at all. I though it would be a darker beer. It was a little like Olde Suffolk. Hid the alcohol very well. It definitely had that am Smith underlying flavor. I was surprised by the dark bottle, which is rare for Sam Smith beers. Id usually take a Belgian over a Brit beer any day, but this was very nice. It had just enough hops to keep it from being cloying.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a murky, light to medium brown with orangey highlights and a small, off-white head that mostly diminished and left virtually no lacing. It actually looked a little like apple cider. The aroma had moderate to heavy caramel malt; lighter molasses, a hint of hops; raisin, prune, apple, toffee butterscotch, fig, apple cider; and slight alcohol. The flavor got better and better as it warmed. The initial flavor was sweet; while the finish was rather sweet, lightly bitter and slightly sour with a fairly long duration. There was caramel, toffee, raisin, a little alcohol, slight butterscotch, apple cider, prune, slight wood, bitter wood and glimpse of hops. The medium body was slightly syrupy and sticky on the lips with soft yet tingly carbonation and a finish with hints of chalkiness.

pours a dark auburn color with hints of orange and a frothy, bubbly orange tan head.  Rich aroma of oak, raisin, bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, soft fruit tones.  Flavor of warm, sweet oak and caramel, pickled fruit, plum, with a soft finish of vanilla pudding and fig which evolves into tones of aged rum and candied fig, sugared pecan.  Smooth, creamy, yet hardened mouth feel, delicious to sip on.  I was skeptical about the high price of this one but it is really a work of art, one of the finest brews Ive had in awhile.  Sam smith always knows what theyre doing.

Most folks, myself included, probably dont know that Stingo is an older word that means old ale or old beer.  Seems appropriate for this beer, which is apparently aged for an entire year in Samuel Smiths famous Yorkshire Squares.  Im using a goblet for this one tonight, as a special beer deserves a special glass.  Pours a murky and ruddy amber.  Carbonation levels are pretty high, as theres a constant stream of bubbles popping up from the bottom of the glass.  No real head on this beer, just bubbles on the outer rim of the glass.  Aroma is rich, deep, and pungent.  You can really pick out the oak, which adds a nice earth characteristic.  The first taste is simply incredible.  Flavor profile is stunningly complex, with loads of molasses, dark cherry, raisin, oak, and tobacco clamoring for attention on the palate.  This beer has the perfect amount of carbonation to keep the mouthfeel balanced, as the heavy flavor profile and malt profile could easily become syrupy if left alone.  Happily thats not the case here, though the heavy alcohol warmth makes this a sipping beer.  Samuel Smiths has done it again, creating a textbook example of a classic English style  in the case of Yorkshire Stingo, the Old Ale.  Highly recommended.

pours a cloudy dark brown color with a nice mostly white head. aroma is woody vanilla and sweet fruit. medium carbonation. taste is creamy and woody with some dark cherries and vanilla in the finish. not too bad but not something i would go out of my way to try again.

Hazy brownish amber with a generous tan head, strong retention and excellent lace. Wonderful caramel aroma with vanilla, dark fruit - raisins, figs and cherries, a hint of oak and a plug of tobacco. Rich caramel and dark fruit flavors burst forth on the tongue with a touch of hops to offset the sweetness. Oak is evident throughout. Medium to full body, moderately carbonated, creamy mouthfeel, warming alcohol, and a gentle fruit sweetness lingers in the aftertaste. Not quite the 100 that Draft gives it, but sinfully good nonetheless.

18.7 oz bottle. Hazy copper with a small creamy beige head that quickly fades to a ring. Aroma of dates, raisins, caramel, vanilla and oak. The flavor is sweet caramel malt, boozy alcohol and a light oaky finish. Medium body with mild carbonation and a slick mouth feel. Nice beer, like a light Barley Wine. Glad I tried it but not sure its worth $12 per bottle.

I never gave this beer a second thought until I read a review in Draft Magazine. Im sure glad I did. Pours a murky brown with an off white head. The aroma is sweet malt, raisins and other fruit along with some wood and vanilla. The flavor is malty sweet with the dark fruits, not a hop to be found. Very nice for sipping.

Blah! I just cant get into English beers. Aroma was all wood with a slightly metallic note. Pour was a dark murky brown with a one finger near tan head. Taste was very English. Very woody with hints of raisin and toffee. Has almost a dusty character. Musty and metallic aftertaste. If the English are raving about this beer I cant imagine how happy theyd be to live in the US
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. Pours with a minimal mostly white head; very hazy reddish brown orange thats lighter in hue.  Caramel and toffee in the aroma with a slight alcohol kiss and a light fruity yeastiness.  Flavor is raisiny, dark sweet grapes, caramel again..not much oak but a tad there.  Medium to thinner body, with subdued carbonation.  Slightly sticky, but a fruity dry finish.  Nice sipping brew.

550 ml bottle from the Four Firkins.  Cloud caramel colored pour with a creamy white head.  Aroma is massive sweet oaky aroma with some dark fruit notes.  Flavor is more oak, a bit of dark fruit and the toffee comes through as well.  Lingering oaky finish.  Fantastic beer.

Bottle. Bright red. Aroma is dark breads and dried dark fruit. Palate is prickly and wish it were from a cask because of it. Has a full body. The sweet fruity and bread crust flavors are fantastic. Balanced. The kirsch-like finish is potent, and becomes noticeably fruitier with each sip. Nice stuff

Big thanks to jampics2 for sending this extra my way.

A: Pours a dark caramel-amber with a nice light tan head.

S: Loaded with sweet malt, caramel, and toffee; accompanied by plenty of fruit and hints of vanilla.

T: Doesnt pop quite like the nose, and a little bit of wood makes its way in.

M: Medium body with good carbonation.

D: Very nice all around. Havent been disappointed by Sam Smith yet.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-15-2010

Plum and prune nose with a sweet roasted caky, malt base. Cloudy light ochre, thin yellow head.  Leathery sweet malt with maraschino cherry notes. Subtle overripe orange finish. Alcohol noticeable, but works. This is a nice warming holiday beer, reminiscent of fruitcake. Not really my type of beer, but I can appreciate why some people would like it.

Bottle.  Slightly hazy amber with a caramel head.  The aroma is chewy with accented fruitiness (cherry, plum, sultana) and some background earthiness.  Very chewy palate sits heavy and sticky without any particular nuance.  The oak shows a fair bit, but at no point does it sufficiently balance this brews dull, heavy-handed malts.  I dont know much about stingo, but this one isnt really my thing.

Bottle.  Pours dark red, with a medium sized lingering tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, clove, and booze.  Flavor is only moderately sweet, balanced by a not insignificant twinge of alcohol burn on the tongue.  Mouthfeel is surprisingly soft and drinkable.  Balanced, complex, and lovely.

Sweet and sour malt aroma with barrel notes, and a gentle smokiness. Strong taste of raisins, malt and figs, completed with nice flavors from aging in oak casks.  The alcohol is hidden well by the sweet rich taste. Strangely enough, the aftertaste is a bit watery. A good beer with a quite different taste, I like it!

Nothing like the Watneys Stingo of old. The color is a particularly refractive cognac/amber, and there are esters of raisin, plum, cherry, treacle, toffee, vanilla, plum pudding in hard sauce, and oak. The body is medium and oily, and the flavor and carbonation are very soft.

Its a sweet brew, on balance, but never cloying, with just enough flowery hop dryness in the finish, and a lot of finesse.

7th beer from the 7th country for the evening and what a way to go out. Very flavorful. Rich, smoky, not too heavy, but quite coating feeling in the mouth, really quite tasty. LIghter in color than expected but excellent nonetheless.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2016 Refrigerated bottle poured into a chalice.  Pours a opaque mahogany/amber with medium dense head that dissapates over time.  Aroma is beautiful toffee, rich body, little lacing, and tight medium lacing.  Taste is dark fruit (mostly fig), some toffee, a little caramel, hint of butterscotch, and finishes a little hoppy.  Nice complexity, but not quite as good as some of the best Belgian beers.

Pours out a bubbly light tan cap that lasts a very long time, mahogany brew that is totally clear. I actually listened to the instructions on the bottle for once cause I love Sam Smith brews so I did not pour in the muck. Slippery dissipating lacing. The aroma is excellent - better than that camping trip in Montana when I placed my tent near a pile of rotting gophers - yes - a pile. My girl at the time is now my wife.. maybe she has a maggot filled rodent fetish. Oh! The beer.. yessss... so easily distracted. Slightly sweet, caramel, some paint fumes, raisin, red berries, toffee, earth, those dried fruit nuggets in trail mix. Taste is is is is is sis siellllljg9=3-4=ug9. Shit, this is chewy. toffee, some alc notes that are quite light but noticeable early on, dark raisins, weak spices, dull cherry, light wood, more alc taste. Id love if that wasnt there. Then again, this isnt that stellar of a brew. A bit oily mouth, sort of drying, faint hop on the finish. At 15 clams Ill never revisit this unless I buy another one....

Bottle. Saddle brown pour with barely any carbonation.  Complex bouquet of figs, raisins, dates, honey, and oak.  Moderately sweet malt flavor with booziness and toffee flavors.  The flavor palate isnt quite as robust as the aroma which is a little disappointing.   Even still, you definitely want to sip this or risk missing something.  I would have loved slightly more mouthfeel.  Overall its pleasant and drinks like a whiskey or cognac

(500ml bottle, 2008 vintage)  Pours a cloudy burnt orange body with a medium cream head.  Aroma of old books, caramel, wood, raisins, cherries, vinous, toffee, and toasted coconut.  Flavor of caramel, roasted malt, toasted bread, wood, raisins, slight oxidation, and toffee.  Nicely complex.

sample from the bottle @ Hotoberfest in Atlanta on 10/2/10.  deep copper pour with a slim white head.  deep fruit filled nose with some sweet malts.  big sweet mouthfeel with lots of sugar, grape, raisin and plum notes.  sweet finish with more fruit.  overall a really nice strong ale, but too sweet.  a little bit goes a long way...
UPDATED: DEC 10, 2010 10/2/10.  Bottle.  Plain, sweet aroma with not much going on.  Big sweet, slightly tart and slightly oxidized flavor.  Meh.

2009 vintage.  Enjoyed from a 1 pint nine ounce bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a medium amber color, with essentially no head.  The aroma is somewhat slight, before revealing some malt sweetness, a slightly oxidized note, some oak, and a slight note of alcohol.  The palate is surprisingly light and subtle in flavor, given the beers gravity.  The palate shows an almost minty oak character in the approach, before showing some residual malt sweetness, and depth-adding alcohol.  Again, the flavors show a level of finesse and subtlety that is surprising from a strong ale.  Hops do not show themselves in terms of aroma, flavor, or noticeable bitterness.  Carbonation is nicely dialed in.  The finish leaves a lingering not of oak, along with a touch of alcohol.  Overall, a quaffable strong ale that shows more finesse and somewhat less aggression than American examples of the style.

Wow, this is a really nice brew. Deep red color. This isnt nearly as dark as I was expecting. Very strong, bold, dried fruits with nuts, mild roots, and wood. Very light soy sauce. I mean barely perceptible. Almost hints at being Belgian, but its not. Imagine a Belgian strong ale, with some some of the yeast cut back. The alcohol comes through, but not really representative of how high the ABV is. This is a really complex beer. Feels nice on the palate, too. Its got a little skin to it, if you know what I mean. Only complaint is its like thirteen bucks for (I think) 18oz. Its good, but I dont know about thirteen dollars good.

From bottle. Biscuit and caramel, sweet malt with light alcohol and brown sugar. Mild hop notes with a metallic tang, mild pear and neutral fruit. Light woody notes, and just a bit of butterscotch. Hazy dark amber that clears as it warms, topped with thin off-white head. Medium-heavy body with medium-high carbonation. Warming. Starts sweet with caramel, brown sugar, and neutral fruity notes. Woody notes with medium dry bitterness. Alcohol sweetness. Finish is sweet with bitter undertones and light carbonic dryness. Sweet nutty after. Pretty smooth and hides the 9% well.

Pours murky (clears up as it warms, I poured it too cold by all indications), ruddy brown, with a 1 finger chunky, beige head that has good retention. Aroma is dark fruit, toffee, woody notes, sweet bread spice, apple pie, and sweet caramel, overall the aroma is surprisingly weak(gets stronger as it warms, but becomes a bit too strong on the dark fruit and gets a little boozy), but quite nice. Flavor is of caramel covered bread pudding with raisins, spiced apple pie filling, lightly burnt toffee, light, earthy wood notes, a touch of piney hops and a touch of crusty white bread. Palate is medium bodied, dry and thin feeling on the palate, its not bad, but this beer would definitely do well with a fuller mouthfeel. Overall, a nice, tasty brew, but it didnt quite live up to what I was hoping for, based on the description.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a small amount of head.  Strong sweet malty flavor with a lasting finish.

550ml bottle from Brewery Creek. Pours a deep orange with slight head. Nose is fruity esters, toffee, earth, cardboard, apples, plum and other dark fruits. Flavor is sweet fruits, berries, cherry, oxidation, damp mustiness, sweet toffee and caramel. Oily full bodied beer. Reminded me favourably of the better years of Fullers Vintage Ale. Very nice.

550ml brown bottle. First off, gotta say that I am happy to see the brewery moving to brown bottles. This was surprisingly tasty and took me by surprise. Big cloudy amber pour with a decent head. Sweet malt taste with raisin. Not too heavy with alcohol flavor despite being on the stronger side on the abv scale.

Sam Smith is no longer my favorite brewer, only because I have found so many more over the years.  But it may still be my favorite UK brewer on average.  This is a brownish orange, dark, very cloudy but not opaque pour with a large tan head and good lacing.  Nose of vanilla, oak, caramel.  Taste of sour old wood (like a Flemish red maybe), vanilla, caramel, sweet malts, and hops, plus some Christmas pudding notes.  Very nice beer.

Pours a lovely, dark, cloudy red-brown.  The body is good and hearty, and the flavor is that of sweet malts, but with a lot of lactic sourness.  Id almost suggest someone try this beer and learn to enjoy it before trying Flemish sour ales.  To me, this ale almost seems like a milder version of that.  I really like it.  Quality is what Ive come to expect from Samuel Smith, which I think is probably the best brewery going in the UK.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2010 Aroma is heavy burnt caramel. Oak is present. I can tell that this beer will be complex from the aroma. I can smell that it also has high alcohol content. Appearance is medium dark brown, hints of orange. Half finger tan head that does not disapate quickly. Nice lacing that will harden to the glass like merengue. Head pops over the top of my glass without spilling. Perfect for an english pint glass. Taste is very sweet and complex. Not cloying. Where to begin. Burnt caramel, apple, mild oak, raisin, toffee, cherry, nutty, vanilla, burnt toast, tobacco, roasty, earthy hops, peppery, slight hot alcohol. This is a beer you pick up flavors a full minute after the sip. It keeps going and going. Very complex. Beyond my palate. Palate is full. Alcohol hotness helps keep things in check and not bogged down. Overall this beer excellent and very complex. It is every great english ale flavor combined, and then condensed.
550ml bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a medium head.  Aroma is rasin, toffee malt and a hint of alcohol.  Some wood.  Toffee sweetness starts, raisin follows with a sweet, malty finish.

Pours a beautiful ruby with a thick head. Aroma is raisin and caramel. Flavor is very malt caramel and sweet, with toffee, dark fruit, oak, and maple syrup. Nice but gets difficult to drink after awhile with so much richness going on. Nice beer

Dark copper. Fair lasting head. Toffee, licorice and alcohol aroma. Thick locorice amber syrup flavour. Lots of alcohol. Like a messy, sloppy treacle, alcohol thin tasty treat. Not stellar but freakin interesting.

Hazy brown, her white head fades fast into a thin ringlet. There is no apparent lace to be found nor any remains of her head other than the collar she wears. Thats okay though because an overly ambitious head would just get in the way of her even more overly ambitious nose. Sweet, vinous, fruity, and ripe with dates and raisins. Molasses whispers while cinnamon sugar and brown sugar adorn, unusually so, plums and apricots; fresh jam anyone? Candied sugars, maraschino cherries, and a solid showing of port and sherry character bring me to the old wood she was aged in. Peat brushes my nose and I dip right back in to capture some more; yes indeed, there is a subtle showing of peat and earth behind each sweet and spicy dark fruit port essence of her nose. While her wood-tinged port and sherry notes were in the back of her nose, in her palate they are front and center from first quaff to last. Silky smooth, her body glides across my tongue while coating my lips with plum and apricot. My palate dries almost immediately, creating an insatiable thirst for more, and so I happily oblige. Mixed in with her dry wood notes are cinnamon sticks for added spice even as apricot jam and marmalade slather themselves atop dry toast while raspberries and black plums tantalize. Nothing lingers but an apparent dryness of breath which reminds me of supping an old red wine or old woody port. The more we acquaint ourselves, the more I come to the conclusion that within her complexity, she is a rather simple beer made exquisite by how well her major flavor profiles work together for the ultimate in sessionable barrel-aged beer quaffing.


I can and will easily recommend this beer to anyone looking for a good sit down session where your mind, body, and soul are in that perfect medium of not too much and not too little. For your wine friends who still scoff ignorantly at your beer, pour them some of this and see if they dont change their mind.

Alcohol and wood, dried fruit, and malty aroma and flavor. This beer tastes a bit stronger than its ABV IMO. I got a good whif of bourbon right out of the bottle, and it carried through the last sip. Some yeasty undertones as well. This is perhaps a little more dry and bitter than I prefer, but a nice strong ale, and you can appreciate the aging. I ust get a boozy cling on my tongue. Very little head if poured according to the bottle instructions, and a fair amount of solids in the bottom. A nice ruby brown beer that hints at the strong flavor to come. Tasted from the bottle @ 65F.
pours a deep ruby color with a nice off white head and no lacing.  sweet molasses aroma with some fresh fruit.  taste is woody with fruit and nice alochol finish.

Bottle.
Pours mahogny with some head.
A bit vinous, malty and some oaky carachtere.
Bottle. Pours red-brown with a small white head. Oak, hops and roasted malt in the aroma. The taste has got a strange rough quality with the roasted malt and the oakiness.

(550ml bottle thanks to bu11zeye) opaque almost ruddy orange-brown with a lasting cream head. Nose of brown sugar, vanilla, oak, sweet caramel and light metallic notes. Taste of metal, alcohol, golden raisins, sweet caramel, yeast with a medium body that is well carbonated. Some nice warming alcohol in the finish as well.

Bottled from Systembolaget.
Deep amber. Small tan head.
Sweet and frutiy with resin in both aroma and flavour.
Also some chocolate-flavpir.
Bottle, thanks to larsniclas. Roasted cocoa and nut aroma. Malty chocolate flavor, roasted with cocoa and resin.

2010 vintage, consumed fresh, 550mL bottle.Pours a hazy garnet with a full tan head that recedes at a medium pace.  The aromas explodes with plum, raisin, dark chocolate, and oak, sweet and full.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin, sweet and malty, lower carbonation with an acidic and crisp finish.  The taste underwhelms a bit after all the promise in the nose, but its good.  Theres lots of fruit on the palate, I almost want to say its a bit apple-like.  A solid and interesting beer but Id have a hard time paying the price premium on this, and I doubt that at 8% its one for the cellar.

08 550ml bottle.

Pours a reddish mahogany with a silky tan head.  Nose has pitted fruits, bready malts, caramel and toffee.  Taste has sweet raisins, cherries, plums and a bit of dry oak in the finish.  Medium body drinks well.

This beer has matured on oak casks for over a year and gotten lots of flavour from it. It had a complex mix of flavours sugar, sweetness, caramel, yeast, wood and grapes. Lots of flavour and I probably missed out on 5-10 more noticeable ones. I think this would work better during the colder months of the year with a nice alcoholic warmth to keep you warm while you lean back and sip at this.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured a deep amber with a cream head. nose is wood, vanilla, bready malts, and very sweet.  nice on the palate, bitter fruits, wood, dough, and a sweet malty finish.  very well done beer here.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a hazy orange color with a white head. The aroma is very fruity and is also has a lot of sugar notes. The flavor is strong cherry with some toffee and caramel malt sweetness. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

bottle thanks to bhensonb.  wow i was not expecting this to be as good as it is.  poured amber with a creamy off white head.  aroma was caramel, orange, toasted grains, golden raisin, and oak.  flavor was caramel, golden raisin, dry oak, alcohol, and what seemed to be like a blood orange flavor.  body was medium with medium carbonation.  very good stuff!!!!

Hazy brown pour with a short lived, 1 finger, off-white head.  Lots of dark fruit, caramel, toffee and brandy aroma with a little bit of damp oak, nutmeg, cinnamon notes.  The flavor is lots of boozy fermenting prunes and raisins with notes of amaretto, licorice, leather, tobacco, some fusel alcohol, pepper, oak, and vanilla.  Oily, full body with soft carbonation.
Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more.  I heard this was one of the higher rated SS beers, but I freaking hated it, poured it out.

Bottle from Bitter End, Bromley. Clear reddish-brown pour with a beige head, lasts a long time. Good carbonation. Treacle toffee, baked apple, brown sugar, sultanas, oak, cinammon. Nice, rich nose. Caramel, butterscotch, licorice, cloves and cinammon flavours. Malty and bitter finish. Nice alcohol burn.

550ml bottle at The Bayou 
Appearance: Pours hazy amber with a nice beige head with little lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, oak and vanilla 
Taste: Sweet malts, vanilla with a slightly bitter finish 
Nice and drinkable, about fell off the chair when I got the bill.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 Samuel Smiths is a class act.  I have enjoyed every beer I have had from them and this was no exception.  Reddish brown color.  Tastes of raisins, oak, toffee, tad of buttery-caramel. Strong but not overly syrupy. Lovely.  Serving: Bottle

Had from 550ml bottle from BevMo.  Pours hazy amber with thick two-finger head and ample lacing.  Aroma is lots of sweet fruits, raisins, toffee, and malts.  Taste is complex with the alcohol just coming out at the end of a complicated sip of malty sugars, raisins, prunes, subtle oak flavors, and caramel.  I was very surprised by this beer and really enjoyed it.  A rare exceptional offering from Samuel Smith.

Bottle.

Brownish with a tan head. Aroma and taste of syrup, bread, some chocolate, vanilla, malt, dark fruit, raisins, spices and caramel. Also some alcohol, especially in the finish. Nice with the information on the back label. A good beer that might benefit from storage?

Bottle:Reddish copper brown colour, firm head. Aroma is raisins, toffee, cherries and oak casks. Thick and sweet mouth feel. Flavour is quite sweet and has notes of oak casks, toffee & liquorce. Alcohol bitter finish.

Bottle (55 cl) from Systembolaget. Clear orange brown, medium beige head. Fudgy and caramelly malt aroma, with some earthy hops, and some vague wooden notes. Medium bodied and smooth. Dry with medium bitterness.
Thanks to Tim for sharing this beer. This reddish pour had a nice flavor. It was on the sweet side but not too sweet. I enjoyed it.
Bottle: Poured a reddish color with little head. Aroma is fruit and oak barrel. The taste is sweet malt and oak.

Vintage brewed in 2008. Pours amber with a tan head. Notes of fruit and a subtle, rich oak flavor. Smooth and very drinkable, with a lightly carmelized taste. Very well balanced. I like this one quite well. Thumbs up.

Was perhaps a bit careless when pouring and got a lot of sediment in the glass, but its still a nice copper-to-brown beer to look at. Aroma is discrete of dried fruit.  The taste malty sweet, more dried fruit and alcohol, backed nicely by bitterness. Caramel too.  The bitterness stays for a while, some tastes of tobacco.  Quite a full mouth but nice, very nice.  Though dangerous I bet.

Bottle, suited the marinated and grilled turkey fillets, wild rice and some nice sallad really well - 2010-05-30, Göteborg

AP: brown/black, rocky head, frothy, brown foam, 
AR: caramel, nuts, roasty, resin, butterscotch, raisin, vanilla, woody
F: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, oily feel, soft carbonation, long finish I been longing for this one for a while

Extra plus for the old label and the very informatative back label with illustration!
Bottle. Clear amber colour with huge creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Sweet malty aroma. Too sweet.

Pours a darker amber. Off white head that slowly fades to lace. Aroma  of oak, caramel, and malt. Fruity  caramel sweet flavor. Bubbly mouth feel. Alcohol is noticeable, but not over done. Light, smooth short lasting dry finish. It is a interesting brew and overall it is pretty good and unique brew. But I dont think I would have another.

Bottle. A strong sweet smell, very drinkable, light fruity. The small white creamy head has a short duration. The body is dark red. The taste is quite sour. The body is light to medium strong with a normal carbonation.

Served from bottle into a Euro pint.  Poured a nice copper color with a two finger off-white head.  No lacing was apparent.  The aroma was comprised of sweet malt and a slight oak hint.  The flavor of this brew was sweet and had a medium feel on the palate with high carbonation.  Overall this was a nicely flavored brew that was quite refreshing.  This was a very nice offering from Samuel Smith.  Too bad it is a limited release...

pours an almost cloudy dark amber with a medium size beige head, and good lacing.

smell is of whisky, wood, malt, and some caramel.

taste is thick, toffee, some spice, malt, and some dark fruits hiding in the back, ends smooth and a tad bitter.
Bottle at Birroteca Tana di Luppolo.  Clear amber color, edge head.  Aroma of oak barrel and port wine.  Taste starts malty, slightly sweet, with a whisky finish.  Very nice.

reddissh copper colored beer, offwhite head.  smells of dried plums, pears, raisins, woody, hoppy.  tasts of woodresins, sherry-like, caramel-toffee, coffee, fruits, hops.  aftertaste is bittersweet, fruitpunch, toffees.

Brownish apricot app with minimal white head. Aroma of sugar, resin, oak and raison. Barleywine-like flavor. Caramelized sugar, alcohol, maple, raison and oak. An interesting lemony, citrus additive as well

550ml bottle, amber-orangeish color, with a beige head, yeasty, toffee, toasted, biscuity malt nose with a winey, raisiny, plumy fruitiness, and some hints of wet oakiness, with a faint vinous aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, raw toasty, biscuity, caramel malt,  winey, fruity, sour character with a mild ripe apple, juicy plumy, dark dried raisin flavour, with a hint of vanilla oakiness, leading towards a warming, winey, juicy plumy, raisiny finish.

Pours copper with a decent beige head and a toffee aroma. There is a hearty pale and caramel malt flavor with lots of treacle and a little dark fruit. The mouthfeel is carbonated and there is some lingering hop bitterness.

550 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Pours a cloudy orange amber color with a small off-white head.  The aroma after some swirling gave sweet fruity and malty notes enhanced with vanilla and a touch of wood.  The flavor is caramel malts, ripe fruits, apple cider, vanilla and some wood.  Medium bodied; the alcohol remains hidden.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2011 Pours a dark amber with a creamy off-white head. Nose of dark fruits, sweet malts and alcohol. Deep flavor, rife with toffee, vanilla, spices and raisins, along with quite detectable whiskey. Sweet and warm finish. A nice beer overall. (3.6)

Update: Shared a bottle at The Rake in London and really enjoyed it. A solid strong ale. (4.0)

Bottle from BevMo.  Pours a cloudy, rusty brown with a 2 finger thick beige head.  Some raisins, dates and clove spice in the nose.  Flavor starts with fruit then gives way to a strange metallic acidity with some faint barrel notes.  A little over rated for $12.99 a bottle.

550 ml. bottle. Vintage 2008. Pours an initially large off white head, which gradually collapses over a clear dark amber (SRM 10) body.........nose is caramel/toffee, bit of cheese, and light dried fruits......taste initially is sweet malt with a bit of toffee/caramel, then dried cherry and raisin, followed by light hop bitterness, alcohol and wood both are well hidden.....mouth feel is medium to slightly chewy, carbonation low. This is a very subtle beer. Every thing balances out nicely, and is done with a very gentle hand. It has all of the qualities it should, and is not over done. BJCP 7/3/15/5/7
bottle, via trade with sprinkle, orange amber colored with bubbly foam, aroma of caramelly sour fruit, flavors of caramel with sour fruit and some watery malt

Bottle. Pours clear amber with a pleasant white  head. Aroma consists of caramel, bread, resin, raisins, dark fruits, and a hint of alcohol. Taste is cloyingly sweet which tastes almost sour and has a little bitterness present with the alcoholic yet lively mouth feel.
Brown with a dense yellow head. Fruity aroma of peach, mango, pineapple, raisins and a bit of oak and smoke. Sweet sugarish flavour with a dry bitterness.

Thanks to ibrew2or3 for this one.

A:  Pours light orange with a rather small head.

S:  Sweet malt aromas with notes of brown sugar and light booze.

T:  Sweet candy malt, caramel, brown sugar, and toffee.  Light oak from the barrel.

M:  Medium in body, pretty nicely carbonated.

D:  Not too bad.  Worth a try.

Bottle.  Pours a an amber body with an off white head.  Oak y body with dark fruit raisins, dates, light fig and some vanilla hints, the aroma is nice with just a hint of astringency.  A bit rough around the edges showing a bit too much etoh with a light vodka esk booziness with mild fruit tones and toffee.  Decent offering.

Bottle [550ml] shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry. Pours a deep amber with an average size mostly-lasting creamy off-white head. Nice aroma of caramel malt, toffee, dark fruit, a hint of nuts and some booze. Flavour of caramel malt, toffee, dark fruit and some alcohol. Medium bodied. Very good, well done.

Pours hazy copper-brown, with a medium beige head, fine and lasting lacing.  Woody, vanilla aromas, with notes of toast, figs, caramel, citrus, and grass.  Medium body, velvety, zesty, crisp.  Honey sweet flavor, vanilla and spice, softly sweet dark fruit mid-palate with notes of raisin bread, and a mild earthy and grassy finish.  The English ale yeasts are most apparent in the finish.  A touch sweet overall, but quite nice.

550 ml bottle, brewed in 2008.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours a copper/brown color with about an inch and a half off-white head.  Head retention is good, but not much lacing.  Aroma is pretty interesting, I can smell caramel and bready malt, dark fruit (cherries, raisins), oak, booze and some tart apples.  Taste is similar to the aroma, it tastes like dark fruit (figs, raisins), oak, caramel, tart apples, molasses and some pears.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit slick with moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is good, its smooth and its easy to drink.  Id buy this again in the future, I think its a good overall brew.

Bottle from Whole Foods Los Altos.  Pours a brilliant but slightly hazy reddish-amber color with a one-finger whitish head.  Aroma is fruity and malty mostly.  Raisin, cherry, oak, and caramel stand out.  Flavor is very nice and fruity.  Cherry, raisin, and other fruits, oak barrel, caramel, toffee, and spiced pudding.  I had heard this described as a bit sour, but I found it to be only mildly tart.  Smooth on the palate with medium-body and no hint of the 8% ABV.  Nice beer overall, I like this a lot.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2010 Bottle shared with Pop.  Looks like iced tea w/out the lemon.  Thin dissipating head.  Oak nose wet leaves and light caramel. There is a word in my notes that i can not discern. "duddsjirgh."
bread, soured milk,red/brown, acetic, short finish,light body, oily feel, soft carbonation, acetic, good beer.

A difficult rating. At first a real good ale, but after an hour in the glass it went acetic and unpleasent. 
Has a fine apperance, brown and hazy, huge head, lasting. Aroma of fruit and fresh water, later a bit unpleasent acetic. Flavor went acetic too. Could bee awesome, but....no, not.

Pours orange amber with tan frothy head.  Caramel, malt, fruit and touch of spice on the nose.  Flavor is big with caramel and dried fruit.  Slight wood hints with bits of vanilla and apple chips.  Good carbination and decent mouthfeel

bottle...Cloudy medium amber pour , thin off white head , sparse lacing . Aroma of fruit ,caramel and oak . Flavor is malty sweet with notes of fruit ,toffee and raisins . Smooth slightly bitter finish , with a touch of  alcohol warming . Medium bodied ,very smooth and drinkable .

Thanks to IBrew2or3 for the share.  Pours orange amber with a white head.  Nose is pudding, fruit, vanilla, malt, caramel, and bourbon.  Flavor is an English Barreled beer: interesting.  I get honey, pudding, vanilla, caramel, malt, and slight barrel/ bourbon.  Medium body and finishes with lingering sweetness.

Bottle at Tampa tasting.  Poured a hazy amber color with the body supporting a thin beige.  Nose is malty with notes of caramel, raisin, and some mild hops.  Medium body with a smooth mouth feel.  Flavor is roasted malt, raisin, caramel, candi sugar, and mildly bitter hops.  Round finish with slight warming alcohol.

Pours a hazy medium brown with an off-white head that disappears pretty quickly.  The aroma is a mix of dark fruits, malts and hops.  This beer tastes a bit lark dark fruit but has a sweetness around the back of the tongue.  This flavor is a bit unique.  While tasty, it isnt the easiest beer to drink.

(Sample Date: 11/28/2009   Source:Once Apon a Vine - Northside)   550 ml bottle 8% abv. Caramel with some woodiness and earthy hops in aroma. Lightly cloudy dark amber/copper with little head. Sweet caramel and dark fruitiness. Medium finish with some woodiness. Mouthfeel is slightly fizzy. Finish is woody. Old Ale close to an English style Barleywine. Alcohol warming is subtle. Quite tasty.

Bottle from the 2008 brewed batch. Pours with a very large rocky/frothy light khaki head and a hazed orange brown body. Aroma of oak, light sourness, cherries, treacle, metal, christmas fruit cake. Flavor is slightly tart and bitter, tons of dark deep toffee notes, raisin bread, and a slight rum richness up front. A bit of cotton candy (not in a Belgiany way) in the aftertaste. Lightish carbonation. Medium acidity. Unique to say the least.

Bottled. Pours clear, deep amber with a large beige head. Fair lacings. Nose of over riped fruits and light malt. Sweet flavour with caramel, fruits, raisins, wood and oak. Medium to full bodied. Oily texture. Dry finish and really no bitterness.
bottle 550 ml from GBBF 2009 color: amber no head, Taste: light sweetness, medium bitterness  butterscotch, raisin, woody oak Palate: bit oily  astringent pleasant way

Thanks Beth101, been waiting for this for a while. Lovely rich malt, caramel aroma with hints of fruit. Nice amber colour with a decent tan head. Caramel flavour, nutty with malt. Good texture. The beer seems well crafted as expected from Sam Smiths. The High ABV gives it an alcoholic kick. The beer delivers this well to unlike some other beers. Oak flavours come out as it warms. Very nice beer.

Bottle ( 550ml ).  Shared with blankboy and garthicus.  Slightly hazy reddish-amber with an average beige frothy head.  Hazy that Sam Smith apple-fruity yeast smell, a bit nutty, modestly boozy - mostly fruity/boozy.  Tastes like an apple-y boozy trippel with some odd oiliness.  Slightly watery, astringent and boozy, with a weird nutty bitter linger.  I like it, but I dont get all that Christmas character they talk about.

Thanks to HogTownHarry for sharing this with Blankboy and I. Appearance: Copper body with a  medium thick, slightly brown head. Aroma: Vanilla, winter fruit, raisins, plums, toffee and (like the commercial description) Christmas pudding. Very nice indeed. Flavour: Quite a thick mouthfeel, alcohol is evident at first but mellowed out pretty quickly, raisins, copper, spice and a long toffee and oak finish. I can imagine sitting in a pub in Yorkshire with my buddy Chris sipping this by the fire.

550 mL bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a slightly hazy copper color with a large tan creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is strong toffee notes with some wood, raisin, other dark fruits, orange zest, caramel and sawdust. Taste is surprisingly tart. Cherries, cranberries, raisin, wood, caramel. Medium bodied.

Pours a thick latherous head that lingers on a hazed amber liquid. Smells of sweetness and minerals. Full nectar w/ mild effers. A watery feel although full. The sweetness factor is low and has an exotic acidity to it like kiwi fruit. Muted caramel, minerals, aged stonefruit, dusted bubblegum, roasted coffee bean. The finish lingers. Very old world in style. A delicious brew.

Pours a hazy caramel brown with a thick creamy beige head that recedes slowly and leaves very good lacing.

The aroma is sweet with lots of caramel malts, brown sugar and a surprisingly big wood presence.  Im also getting lots of booze-soaked plums and raisins.

The taste is even oakier with a sticky sweet dark fruits and caramel malts anchoring things underneath.  The finish is sweet with toffee but still dry with lots of oaky tannins and spiciness lingering.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied with good carbonation but still seems slick and sticky nonetheless.

Im definitely digging this one as its definitely a very sweet beer but with a nice balancing job being done by the barrel character.  Really nice beer.

Bottle. A muddy golden ruby color with a lasting two finger light tan head , some spotty lacong left behind , light to medium carbonation . Aroma of apple skins , raisons, sweet toffee malt , oak , burbon and a hint of horse blanket . Flavor is malty with a light anount of funk , yeasty , bready with a little more of the burbon type note coming through , rasins and at times hints of apple. Fairly bitter , malty , medium body with a slick mouthfeel , and a spicy hop finish . This was a strange brew for sure but the more of it I drank the more I liked it , not sure I would call it sessionable , but quite interesting .

Bottle on 11/28/2009. Somewhat cloudy dark amber body with a medium creamy off-white head. Sweet caramel, and light molasses aroma with some earthy hop notes. Sweet caramel and sugar flavor with an earthy malt background. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation.

Bottle shared by TheCaptain on New Years Eve. Thanks for busting this one out Mark. It poured a dark shade of copper with a foamy khaki head. Though the nose was faint it was very complex. Notes of pit fruit, toffee, vanilla, and a slight sourness. The flavor had all of the notes from the smell along with some soft tannins from the wood, and a general fruitiness. Nothing really stood out, it was a very well rounded beer. A nice subtle slow sipper. Perhaps a bit too expensive however.
Pours a hazy deep orange with a thin off white head. Aroma is oaky malty some vanilla. Fla or is similar. Big malt kind of a soft mouthfeel.  Good oaky beer. Nice mouthfeel.

Bottled. A deep red beer with a huge lazing tan head. The aroma has notes of over ripe fruits, malt, caramel, and a bit of raisins. The flavor is very sweet with strong notes of over ripe fruits as well as medium notes of caramel and malt as well as light notes of raisins, leading to a dry and bitter finish. The alcohol tickles the tongue.

50cl bottle.  Medium beige head atop hazy copper body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, raisin, some plum, light toffee.  Taste is moderately sweet, raisin, caramel, some plum, light alcohol warming.  Smooth medium body.

Pours cloudy caramel color with thin off white head.  Aromas of apples, toffee, figs, raisins and some alcohol. Fruity and caramelly flavor with a touch of oak and some booziness. The flavors dont live up to the aromas for me. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Bottle from Bottleworks.

Served on the high side of cellar temperature. This is one good-looking beer; pours a beautiful red-brown with a modest and coarse/short-lived head but abundant lacing and a long-lasting rim of foam around the edge of the glass. Theres a tremendous amount going on in the aroma: apples and dates, old wine barrels and oak, toffee. Flavor is drier than anticipated given the aroma, but by no means bone dry; instead, we get an interesting blend of sourness (more in the brown ale vein than the sour ale vein) and damp old oak with dark dried fruits and sherry, any earthy bitterness closing the whole thing out. Enjoyable mouthfeel, certainly not hot nor particularly thick, but quite fulfilling once the palate adjusts expectations. Nice beer but perhaps not exceptional.

500 mlk bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a lasting amber head., Aromas of plum, raisin, molasses, oak and light vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and sdmooth with a dry finish., Flavors of  plum, raisin, oak, toffee, light molasses and light vanilla with a smooth dry lingering fruity finish.

Deep copper in colour, with a massive, frothy head and moderate carbonation. Aroma of caramel, sweet, overripe red fruit, nuts and oak. Flavour of barley sugar,  more wood and fruit sugars. Finish was dryish but marred by over-prominent alcohol. Good.

Appearance: Pours a near clear, dark amber-hued ody with a medium-small, bubbly, off-white head.

Smell: A nose of caramel-coated, toasted biscuit tops provide a nice sweet-smelling scent accented by notes of dried fruits and spicy English hops. 

Taste: Begins with a taste of sweet, luscious caramel with a deep, dark sugary tone to it along with some lightly toasty biscuit hints and a notable fruitiness coming across as raisins and dehydrated apricots ready for the trail mix bag. Mild spiciness and bitterness from the English hops. Only a minor perceived woody character seems to have been imparted by the oak staves. A bit mineral-laden on the back half. Theres a little leftover malt sweetness on the otherwise lightly spicy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Just a skosh above medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Not bad! Its quite good, in fact, though, at the price tag of around eleven bucks per bottle (the real source of the sting-o), I dont see myself returning to it anytime soon.

Name: Stingo
Date: November 21, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Appearance: hazy amber, fine beige head
Aroma: sweet and fruity aroma, dark caramel sweetness
Flavor: sweet fruity flavor, balancing earthyness

Pours a three finger light cream head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Cloudy amber/brown amber color, some floaties. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Honey nose. Flavor is a mellow honey with a hop backbone. Pricey at $11.54 for a 550ml bottle from Glen Beverage Glen, NH.

Pours a clear dark coppery amber with a fairly thick white head. Aroma is strong, yeasty and fruity - mainly pear and banana - with just a hint of malt. Mouth-filling sassy flavor is malty and yeasty with a slightly bitter hoppy undertone and hints of banana, caramel and molasses. Texture is fairly rough and fizzy, and it leaves a somewhat bitter but not nasty aftertaste. Worth a try.
interesting beer nice dark pour lotsa foam, nose is odd sourish but hops in there. mild flavor for the alcohol, some oakeyness and dried fruits make this one id like to get and age

550ml bottle courtesy of dkachur. Pours a cloudy dark amber with a 2 finger creamy light tan head.  The nose is oaky vanilla, light tobacco and caramel.  The taste is raisins, caramel, wood and a touch of sour fruit with some alcohol in the finish.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Nice beer.  Thanks again Dan!

bottle:  tulip:  this brew smelled and tasted like a barley wine.  The oak barrels really come through in this beer, loads of aged, dark sugars, roasted caramels, wood and tons of booze.  Very hard on the senses, overload of taste, smell and feel.  Deep, rich and complex almost syrupy in taste yet thin in body.  Good beer... overwhelming is a good word.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks David Cohen. Hazy brown color with a beige head. Really rich, malty, honey-ish & caramelly aroma with dark fruits, vanilla and oak. Very sweet malty flavor with caramel, raisins, prunes, plums, alcohol, and a bitter spicy finish. Medium to full-bodied, slightly syrupy.

Ok aroma, sweet fruits (pear?).  Appearance is good with very little head that dissipates quickly.  Color is ruby red/copper.    Very smooth mouthfeel.  Sweetness grows as beer warms.  This beer has a kick but the sweetness is weird and I dont like it.

Wow, I wanted to try this beer pretty bad so when I was sticker shocked by the price I had to buckle down and get it anyway. Curse-d $11.99 half liter. Pours deep copper with cherry red hues and firm light tan head. The aroma is sweet with a bit of booze, maple syrup, ripe cherries and sweet malts. The taste begins as sweet as the aroma smells with malts, maple syrup, a touch of vanilla, faint oak and some slick bourbon booze. It ends with some tasty caramel, slight roast and light amounts of sweet malts.

Another great beer from Samuel Smith.  Pours a dark copper/brown with a pungent orange peel, clove, and nutmeg aroma.  The flavor is very soft and delicate; like mild bread pudding with a touch of raisin.  The bread flavor is pronounced.  Very good, drink by itself or with a warm pastry.
Pours attractive clear ruddy brown with a thin cream colored head. Nose is sweet malt and some dried fruit. Same in the flavor with a sweet caramel like finish. Medium mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours cloudy amber with a medium tan head. Citrusy hop nose with some sugar and sweet malt. Sweet malt flavor up front with a bit of bitter hop in the finish. Nicely balanced.

Dark reddish amber with a pretty big and thick pale beige head with a surprisingly good retention. Nice lacings stick along.

A somewhat edgy, yet also round smell. Noticeable spiciness and stingy mix of alcohol and a hint of vinegar. But underneath this edgy character lies a beautiful and smooth malty foundation of dark bread, caramel, fudge and coco powder. Rich cherry-like fruitiness, raisins and nuts. The composition of rich sweet aromas and hints of tartness is definitely interesting, but I dont know if its all together successful.

A pleasant taste, but still hard to really get a grip on. The maltiness is dense and has a rather bready character. Caramel, fudge and some chocolate notes delivers much of the sweetness. Plenty of nutty aromas. Vinous fruits (cherries, red apples). The sweetness is balanced by a rather noticeable tart note, which is actually quite surprising but very pleasant. The beer has distinct "aged" character and it is obvious that is has been barrel aged (dusty cellar, some wet wood and that general taste of oak barrel). In the finish, there is a mild bitterness and a prominent taste of alcohol. Raisins, some herbs and spices rounds it off.

Medium body with a smooth texture. Initially, the carbonation is a little bit too much, but it settles nicely.

Not bad at all, but its not excellent. From such a great brewery I think I would have expected more, but still recommended.

This is strong ale light. The body is much lighter than I would have expected for the style. Its more like a pale ale or ESB in body and flavor. Impressive masking of strength in this one It could be dangerous.

Dark almost still pour.  Aroma of oaky tannins, vanilla, green apple, and toffee.  Flavor is vanilla, caramel, toffee, dark fruit, cardboard, and oak.  This beer is just okay.  At 10 bucks a pop I can think of other beers Id rather spend my limited funds on.  I have a long history with this brewery and I really wanted to like this. I just didnt

Bottle: Mahogany hue with a frothy head spotty lace. The aroma has notes of caramel, earth, paper, wood, and dried fruit., The taste has a heavy bready and treacle toffee overtone along with raisins and prunes. There is a strange medicinal and "clayish" finish. The mouth feel is soft and medium-bodied. This is just weird and not for a lot of good reasons, not a fan...  a big waste of money.

At a tasting, many thanks David, no head, murky dark orange colour bordering on the brown, aroma of overipe oranges, marmalade, and some oxidised notes, flavours of dried fruits compote, ketchup and a strong woody feeling bitterness, some alcohol in the back but not overpowering, thick mouth coating sensation.  Wonderfull and intense sweet sour finish which lasts for ages.

What an outstanding beer! I dig the way the wood plays with the fruity character of the ale, BIG notes of caramel, ripe cherry, plums, dates, hints of vanilla, almonds, and blackberry. Sweet caramel maltyness, and a very mild tartness on the back end. I would drink this all the time if (A) it were available all the time & (B) I could afford to. The mouthfeel is velvety and supple and finishes with  the complex hints of an old oxidized Port wine. Lovely beer!

@ a tasting, thanks David for sharing this one, pours orange to ruby with an off-white head, great aroma of fresh grapes, cherry liquor, toffee, caramel, vanilla and nutty notes, flavors of nuts, wood, then noticable bitterness and zesty feeling accompanied by white wine, cherry liquor, caramel and spicy finish (clove), very nice brew with almost full body.

Pours a deep orange with little to no head. Nose is fruity esters, toffee, earth, cardboard, apples, plum and other dark fruits. Flavor is sweet fruits, berries, cherry, oxidation, damp mustiness, sweet toffee and caramel. Oily full bodied beer. Very nice.

Bottle: wow, very interesting, heering cherry liqueur, limoncello in the aroma, malty, fudge, toffee, chocolate, sugared cherry, toasted caramel, yeast dough, complex, full bodied, oily, good sipping beer.

Bottle. Moderate cookie for the malt, citrusy hops, heavy must and mold for the yeast, with wood, vinegar and toffee in the background. Head is small, fizzy that thins to wispy with larger bubbles, off-white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear dark copper. Palate is medium, watery but a little slick, with a lively carbonation and a dry finish. Very bold and deep, my brother said this was off compared to the last one he had, so Ill give it a re-rate when I get a chance.

11/08/2009:  Samuel Smith Yorkshire Stingo...  Aroma:  Vanilla, caramel, hint of apple.  Appearance: Murky amber color; foamy beige head.  Flavor:  Buttery vanilla; caramel; faint apple; alochol is well-hidden.  Palate:  Medium-bodied; soft.  Overall:  Not bad at all!
1 pt. 2.7 fl. oz. bottle ( 8.0% alc/vol; S81611) shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #138 for this beer.

oh my god. wonderful oak and malt notes on the nose. Also some spice i cant quite pick out. smells sweet. nice brown colored pour with off white head that disappears quite rapidly. subtle sweetness and wood flavor. this is a very delicious beer, great mouthfeel.

Pours pale amber colur with tan head. Nose has a delightful candied character, almost reminding me of holiday candy cane peppermint. On the palate the malt comes through with a biscuity quality, perhaps black tea, and a soft candied sweetness. Easy drinking.

Bottle from Root Cellar.

Poured hazy dark brown color with medium light brown creamy head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Medium toasted malt and wood aroma with a fruit tone. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy fruit and wood flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. 

Good interesting brew.
Muddy, pulpy orange-red body, thin off-white ring of carbonation. Yeasty nose, chalky, with sour oak and leafy must. Sour body with peachy fruit notes, caramel, and musty, cobwebby oak. Interesting.

550ml bottle served in a snifter. Bottle conditioned. Poured a clear amber with a finger of tan head. Malty aroma with some carmelized sugar and a bit of hops. Medium to full bodied. Malt predominates with dark fruit. Some hops in the finish. Just a hint of the oak. I had really high expectations for this as I am a big fan of British beers, but I found it a bit lacking and overpriced.
Hazy amber pour with a thick off white head. Sweet malt, vanilla and oak aroma. Sweet tangy malt taste with touches of vanilla oak.

750ml bottle poured into a snifter. I tried this one at a recent beer tasting and liked well enough to bring one home for a better tasting experience.

Pours an pleasing burnt orange with a thick and bubbly head. It doesnt stick around long though and leaves no lacing on the glass.

Aroma is nice, reminds me of cinnamon and baked apples. The oak conditioning also comes through in the aroma.

The flavor is very intense, initially very sweet but then balances out some. I get the expected oak, with caramel, raisins and a hint of cinnamon too. The finish is only slightly bitter. Mouth feel is nice, not too heavy or light. Slightly oily with mild carbonation.

Overall pretty tasty.

Bottle.  Pours hazy tawny with a large, frothy light brown head, mostly lasting with excellent lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toffee), average hop (herbs, grass), average yeast (earth, leaves) with notes of oak, plum, cherry, and cask.  Medium bodied, mineral texture, lively carbonation, and a metallic finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, heavy acidity, and moderate bitterness.

Great beer.  Pours a cloudy orange, with a slick off-white head.  Aroma is typical of a cask UK bitter.  Flavor is sweet, with hints of caramel, citrus, some dried fruit, and a touch bready.  Im not picking up as much of the oak as the bottle description would suggest.  Palate is medium and smooth.  Overall a highly drinkable beer.
Poured amber brown, caramel, wood, dark fruits, little alcohol, slight bitter finish.

550ml bottle from Country Club Liquors. Murky light brown with a big beige head. Nose is golden raisins, toffee, and a fair amount of oakiness. Flavor is quite fruity with some light bitterness, caramel, and contrasting sweetness. Finish light bitterness.

550ml bottle, with thanks to Gregis for sharing.  Pours a mostly clear lighter brown, iced tea kind of thing, with a decent off-white head.  Aroma is dried and ripe dark fruits, with some oak, toffee, and a little caramel.  Flavor is more of the same, lighter and a little thinner, but coming off the Marshal Zhukovs, thats a given.  Interesting stuff, thanks for sharing Greg!
Slightly sour aroma. Oaky. Caramel as well. Fruit tastes. Very sticky beer all around. Interesting. Lots of carbonation. Much sweeter than Id expect an English ale to be.

THIS IS A MUST TRY BEER IF YOU CAN FIND IT BUY IT.
Everything about this beer is good from the bottle the pour the flovor. Pours caramel in color with a think med off white colored head. Aroma reminds you of caramel appels, and malts. Thick and creamy flavor sticks to your palate and makes you pumped for the next drink. I think you would like this beer even if not a big beer drinker.
